nn4AIbsf.title: Gas sensing properties of SnO2 hollow spheres/polythiophene inorganic–organic hybrids
nn4AIbsf.abstract: SnO 2 hollow spheres/polythiophene hybrid materials were synthesized by an in situ chemical oxidative polymerization method, and characterized by Fourier transfer infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA). It is proved that there is a strong synergetic interaction between the SnO 2 hollow spheres and polythiophene, and the hybrid materials had higher thermal stability than pure polythiophene, which is beneficial for potential application as chemical sensors. Gas sensing tests showed that the gas sensor based on the as-obtained hybrids had high sensor response and good selectivity, as well as comparatively short recovery time to NO 2 at a working temperature of 90 °C. The enhanced gas sensing performance of the hybrids is due to the high surface area of the hybrids and the p–n heterojunction formed between p-type polythiophene and n-type SnO 2 hollow spheres.

w8SvJYor.title: Synthesis, characterization and catalytic property of ceria spherical nanocrystals
w8SvJYor.abstract: Ceria nanocrystals and CuO–CeO 2 composite were prepared via alcohothermal technique using methanol as the solvent firstly and impregnation method. The catalytic activity of the samples was studied for low-temperature CO oxidation. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) showed that the prepared spherical CeO 2 was cubic phase with good crystallinity and narrow particle size distribution. CuO was in non-crystal form in the CuO–CeO 2 composite. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) analysis of the CuO–CeO 2 composite indicated a two-step reduction and the possible presence of reduced copper species. The CuO–CeO 2 composite exhibited obviously higher catalytic activity than CeO 2 due to the synergistic effect.

btJY4Qwd.title: Preparation of Au/sulfonated polystyrene catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation
btJY4Qwd.abstract: Supported Au catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation were prepared by solvated metal atom impregnation (SMAI) and conventional impregnation (CI). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) investigations indicated that the elemental gold in all the samples was in the metallic state. XRD measurements showed that the mean diameters of Au particles prepared by SMAI were smaller than those prepared by CI with the same gold content. Catalytic tests showed that the SMAI catalyst had higher CO oxidation activity than the CI catalyst with the same compositions. Both SMAI and CI catalysts exhibited high activity in low temperature CO oxidation. Full CO conversion was obtained at 323-383K.
btJY4Qwd.venue: Chinese Journal of Polymer Science (English Edition)

vMTdmtp7.title: Preparation and gas sensing properties of γ-Fe2O 3 nanopowders by solid-state grinding method at room temperature
vMTdmtp7.abstract: γ-Fe2O3 nanopowders have been synthesized by solid-state grinding method using Fe (NO3)3·9H 2O, NaOH and polyethylene glycol (PEG-200) as the starting material. The products have been characterized by FTIR, XRD, TEM and gas sensor measuring system. The result suggests that γ-Fe2O3 with particle size about 4-10 nm has been obtained when FeOOH calcined at 300-500 °C for 1 h, while Cu-Fe2O3 can be obtained calcined at 600 °C for 1 h. At the same time, the sensor has high sensitivity and good selectivity to ethanol gas. Besides, α-Fe2O3 nanopowders can be produced when FeCl3 and polyethylene glycol (PEG-200) as the starting materials, indicating that different iron salt precursors and carbon chain length of polyglycol can evidently affect the final products.

e96U7kSJ.title: Characterization and magnetic properties of cobalt nanoparticles prepared by metal vapor synthesis technique
e96U7kSJ.abstract: The metal vapor synthesis technique was employed to prepare Co nanoparticles. The characteristics and properties of the particles were studied by transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, temperature-programmed desorption, chemisorption and magnetic measurements. The experimental results showed that the particle size of Co powders depended on the initial Co concentration in the toluene matrix, reaching the average crystallite diameter of 1.5 nm for the highest concentration (6.4 at. pct) investigated. The particles with the size of 10 nm could exist, due to the agglomerates of microcrystallites. The Co particles were surrounded by a thin carbonaceous layer formed due to toluene decomposition. The carbonaceous layer was composed primarily of C 1 fragments. The Co powders demonstrated ferromagnetic behavior.

Q13IIGKi.title: Preparation, characterization and CO oxidation catalytic properties of CuO/TiO2 catalysts supported on porous microspheres composed of TiO2 nanocrystals
Q13IIGKi.abstract: The porous TiO2 microspheres were prepared by the reversed-phase suspension polymerization and sol-gel method. The CuO/TiO2 catalysts with porous microspheres composed of TiO2 nanocrystals as the support were prepared by impregnation method. The properties of the porous TiO2 microspheres and CuO/TiO2 catalysts were studied by TG-DTA, X-ray diffraction, XPS and ICP. The catalytic properties of the catalysts for CO oxidation were studied via a microreactor-GC system. The results show that the porous microspheres were mainly composed of anatase TiO2 nanocrystals with a size of 19.5 nm. The XPS results indicate that there was interaction between the support and the active component, and Cu mainly existed as Cu2+ with some other form. The catalytic activity of the catalysts depends on the concentration of the impregnation solution and the calcination temperature of the CuO/TiO2 catalysts. The catalyst impregnated in 0.5 mol/L Cu (NO3)2·3H2O had a better catalytic activity. The optimum calcination temperature of the CuO/TiO2 catalysts was 200°C.

tjOjlJAX.title: Syntheses, crystal structures and fluorescent properties of R,R-DIOP based copper (I) and cadmium (II) complexes {R,R-DIOP = (4R,5R)-trans-4,5-bis(diphenylphosphinomethyl)-2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxalane}
tjOjlJAX.abstract: Two chiral complexes, [CuCl(R,R-DIOP)] 2 (1) and [CdCl 2(R,R-DIOP)] n (2), have been synthesized by reaction of CuCl or CdCl 2 with chiral diphosphine ligand R,R-DIOP under argon. They were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, UV-vis, fluorescence spectra and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. X-ray analysis indicates that the metal centers (Cu I for 1 and Cd II for 2) are both in distorted tetrahedral environment, but 1 is a binuclear complex in which Cu I ions are surrounded by two μ 2-bridging chloride ions and two bismonodentate coordinated R,R-DIOP ligands; while 2 is a helical polymer along b axis and each Cd II ion is coordinated with two chloride ions and two P atoms of two μ 2-bridging R,R-DIOP ligands. Both of them crystallize in monoclinic system, space group P 21, with a = 9.8855(7) Å, b = 37.857(3) Å, c = 23.9585(16) Å, β = 92.0920(10)°, Z = 6 for (1) and a = 10.1740(8) Å, b = 13.9899(11) Å, c = 11.4007(9) Å, β = 108.3690(10)°, Z = 2 for (2). Fluorescence measurements show that complex 1 can emits much strong blue emission than 2 at room temperature in the solid state. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Nzgugm5A.title: Catalytic carbon monoxide oxidation over CuO/CeO2 composite catalysts
Nzgugm5A.abstract:
Summary  CeO2 nanoparticles were prepared by thermal decomposition of cerous nitrate and then used as supports for CuO/CeO2 catalysts prepared via the impregnation method. The samples were characterized by XRD, HRTEM, H2-TPR and XPS. The catalytic properties of the catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation were studied by using a microreactor-GC
 system.

3pkvyjKW.title: Base metal catalysts in carbon monoxide oxidation
3pkvyjKW.abstract: The base metal catalysts for CO oxidation have broadened the application of the base metals. Furthermore, these studies have been performing for promising processes in the development of non-precious metal catalysts to replace noble metal catalysts for CO oxidation as an attractive subject of catalysis. The latest progress in the research of the base metal catalysts including copper and cobalt for CO oxidation has been reviewed.

airefVyE.title: Preparation of highly dispersed Au/TiO2 catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation by solvated metal atom impregnation method
airefVyE.abstract: Highly dispersed Au/TiO2 catalysts with different Au content were prepared by solvated metal atom impregnation technique. The results of XRD and transmission electron microscopy show that as the metal content increases the particle size of gold increases; but the diameter of Au particles in all the Au/TiO2 catalysts studied is in the range of 1.8-3.5 nm. XPS study indicates that gold is in metallic state. The Au/TiO2 catalysts demonstrate high activity for CO oxidation at low temperature. At 323 K, 100% CO conversion is achieved. The Au/TiO2 catalyst with gold particle size of 1.8 nm shows the highest activity.

EsQhOj1P.title: The preparation and gas sensitivity study of polythiophene/SnO2 composites
EsQhOj1P.abstract: Nanocomposites of SnO 2 and polythiophene (PTP) were synthesized by the in situ chemical oxidative polymerization method. These nanocomposites were characterized by FTIR, transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TG–DTA) techniques, which proved the polymerization of thiophene monomer and the strong interaction between polythiophene and SnO 2 . The composites were used for gas sensing to methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), acetone, and NO x at different working temperature. It was found that PTP/SnO 2 materials with different PTP mass percent (1%, 5%, 10%, 20% and 30%) could detect NO x with very higher selectivity and sensitivity at much lower working temperature than the reported SnO 2 . The PTP/SnO 2 nanocomposites responded to NO x at concentration as low as 10 ppm. PTP/SnO 2 composite containing 5 mass% PTP showed the highest sensitivity at room temperature. The sensing mechanism of PTP/SnO 2 nanocomposites to NO x was presumed to be the effects of p–n heterojunction between PTP and SnO 2 .

skbwrRhL.title: Structure and activity of polymer immobilized Co-Pd catalysts
skbwrRhL.abstract: Solvated metal atom impregnation (SMAI) method was used to prepare polymer immobilized metal catalysts under mild conditions. Several SMAI Co-Pd catalysts with different metal contents were prepared. These catalysts were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and magnetic measurement. Compared with catalysts prepared by common impregnation (CI) method, the particle sizes of the metal in SMAI catalysts were much smaller. The contents of zero-valent state metallic Co and Pd in SMAI catalysts were higher than those in CI catalysts. The Co atoms were enriched on the surface for SMAI catalysts, whereas the Co atom concentration on the surface was essentially the same as in the bulk for CI catalysts. The catalytic activity of SMAI catalysts was much greater than that of CI catalysts with the same composition in hydrogenation of diacetone alcohol and O2 reduction on fuel cell electrodes.

5rUU081p.title: The effect of au-doping by different methods on gas-sensing properties of α-Fe2O3 nanopowders
5rUU081p.abstract: Au-doped α-Fe2O3 nanopowders were prepared by coprecipitation, impregnation, and ultraviolet irradiation methods, respectively. The Au/α-Fe2O3 nanopowders were characterized by TG-DTA, XRD, and TEM . The effects of dopping methods, the Au content, and the calcination temperature on gas-sensing properties of α-Fe2O3 were studied . The results showed that α-Fe2O3 sensors presented much higher sensitivity after doped with Au. Among them, the Au-doped α-Fe2O 3(w(Au)=1.5%, calcinated at 400°C) prepared by coprecipitation gave the best sensitivity. ©Editorial office of Acta Physico-Chimica Sinica.

XfFRgFRd.title: Morphological evolution of hematite nanoparticles with and without surfactant by hydrothermal method
XfFRgFRd.abstract: Various morphological α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles modified by four surfactants, sodium dodecylsulfonate (SDS), sodium dodecylebenzene sulphonate (DBS), cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) and hexadecyipyridinium chloride (HPC), have been synthesized via hydrothermal method. Meanwhile, α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles without surfactant are also prepared under the same conditions for comparison. The products were characterized by means of IR, XRD, TEM and magnetization measurements. TEM pattern of the α-Fe 2 O 3 without surfactant shows irregular shape with particle size of around 380±50 nm, while the TEM pictures of the products modified by SDS, HPC, DBS and CTAB show fine hexagonal, rhombohedral, subround and hexagonallike shape, respectively, and the corresponding particle size is about 230, 150, 240 and 260 nm, respectively. In addition, although the four products modified by different surfactants all exhibit weak ferromagnetic properties at room temperature, the coercivity values possess obvious change. So, it can be concluded that the surfactants not only significantly influence the shape and size of the particles but also their magnetic properties.

EfesFuIy.title: Preparation,Characterization and Gas Sensitivity Study of Polyaniline/SnO_2 Hybrid Materials
EfesFuIy.abstract: PAn/SnO2 hybrid materials were prepared by hydrothermal and polymeric method,and characterized by FTIR,XRD,TEM and XPS.The gas sensitivity of PAn/SnO2 hybrid to ethanol,H2,CO and NH3 was also studied at low temperature(room temperature,60 ℃ and 90 ℃).It was found that An polymerized at the surface of SnO2 and core-shell type PAn/SnO2 hybrids formed.When the operating temperature reached 90 ℃,PAn/SnO2 hybrid materials had selectivity to ethanol gas,showed short response-recovery time and good reversibility,and could detect ethanol gas at a wide concentration range.

xKZDYDL3.title: Preparation and catalytic activity of Au/SnO2 for low-temperature CO oxidation
xKZDYDL3.abstract: Three Au/SnO2 catalysts with different gold loading were prepared via deposition-precipitation method, and characterized by XRD and UV-Vis. The effects of pH of deposition solution, Au loading and pre-treatment condition on the catalytic activity of Au/SnO2 catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation were investigated. The results showed that (1) the mean Au particle size of Au/SnO2 catalyst prepared at pH = 9-10 deposition condition was the smallest among the samples obtained at different deposition pH; (2) the catalytic activity decreased with the increase of Au loading; (3) among the 2% Au/SnO2 catalyst samples calcined at different temperatures in air for 4 h, the catalytic activity of the sample calcined at 473 K was the highest; (4) the catalyst samples pretreated at low temperature in H2 exhibited higher activity, and the activity of the sample obtained at 373 K for 2 h was the highest among all Au/SnO2 samples in this work.

IbfoQHUQ.title: Application of ultrasound in organic reaction
IbfoQHUQ.abstract: The principle of sonochemistry and ultrasonic apparatus for chemical laboratories are introduced. Applications and uses of ultrasound in homogeneous and heterogeneous organic reactions are also discussed. Ultrasound, in comparison with normal reaction, is able to enhance reaction rates and product yields. Sometimes it may change reaction pathway. Ultrasound may replace phase-transfer catalysts in phase-transfer catalysis reactions and facilitate the reaction.

rzjaF7vM.title: Characterization and catalysis studies of CuO/CeO2 model catalysts
rzjaF7vM.abstract: CeO 2 thin films were prepared via a sol–gel dip-coating process, and used as supports to prepare CuO/CeO 2 model catalysts. The catalytic activity of the catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation was investigated with a micro-reactor-GC system. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns indicate that the CeO 2 films are of random orientation with dominant (1 1 1) texture, and Cu 0.2 Ni 0.8 O phase has formed in CuO/CeO 2 model catalysts. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) images show the CeO 2 film surface is uniform and CuO exists in either cluster or crystal forms. CuO/CeO 2 /Ni has higher catalytic activity compared to CuO/CeO 2 /NiO/Ni. The synergistic interaction between CuO and CeO 2 is the main factor responsible for high catalytic activity of CuO/CeO 2 model catalysts. Keywords Sol–gel dip-coating CeO 2 thin film CuO/CeO 2 model catalyst CO oxidation

Dn8eJAhy.title: Reactive template synthesis of polypyrrole nanotubes for fabricating metal/conducting polymer nanocomposites.
Dn8eJAhy.abstract: Unique nanocomposites of polypyrrole/Au and polypyrrole/Pt hybrid nanotubes are synthesized employing polypyrrole (PPy) nanotubes as an advanced support by solution reduction. The conducting polymer PPy nanotubes are fabricated by using pre-prepared MnO2 nanowires as the reactive templates. MnO2 nanowires induce the 1D polymerization of pyrrole monomers and the simultaneous dissolution of the templates affords the hollow tube-like structure. The loading content of metal nanoparticles in the nanocomposites could be adjusted by simply changing the amount of metal precursors. This work provides an efficient approach to fabricate an important kind of metal/conducting polymer hybrid nanotubes that are potentially useful for electrocatalyst and sensor materials.

Hj7Ejy5k.title: Hierarchical meso–macroporous titania-supported CuO nanocatalysts: preparation, characterization and catalytic CO oxidation
Hj7Ejy5k.abstract:
Hierarchically mesoporous–macroporous titanium dioxide (MMTD) was synthesized by the hydrolysis of tetrabutyl titanate in
 the absence of surfactant and autoclaving at 60 °C, which exhibits a porous hierarchy of wormhole-like mesostructure in the
 framework of macrochannels. Different contents of CuO nanoparticles were supported on the MMTD by a deposition–precipitation
 (DP) method, retaining the high surface areas and hierarchical porosity. The prepared MMTD support and the resulting CuO/MMTD
 nanocatalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy
 (TEM), N2 adsorption analysis, temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) techniques. Their
 catalytic behavior for low-temperature CO oxidation was studied by using a microreactor–GC system, and the CuO/MMTD catalyst
 with 8 wt% CuO content and calcined at 400 °C was found to have the highest catalytic activity. The catalytic activity depended
 on the CuO loading amount, the precalcination temperature, the meso–macroporous framework, the surface area, and the particle
 size of the CuO/MMTD catalysts.

3G5DZdFH.title: Preparation of Nano-Particle Pd/γ-Al2O3 Catalysts for Low-Temperature CO Oxidation by Solvated Metal Atom Impregnation Method
3G5DZdFH.abstract: Nano- particle Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Pd content were prepared by solvated metal atom impregnation technique. The results of XRD and Chemisorption measurement showed that as the metal content increased the particle size of Palladium increased; but the diameter of Pd particles in all the Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts studied was in the range of 2.0-6.0nm. XPS study indicated that Palladium was in metallic state. The Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited higher activity for CO oxidation at lower temperature. 100% CO conversion was achieved at 453K. As the particle size of Palladium increased the catalytic activity increased. The Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with Pd particle size of 2.1nm showed the highest activity.

boRvLEiB.title: Preparation, characterization and gas sensitivity study of polyaniline/SnO2 hybrid materials
boRvLEiB.abstract: PAn/SnO2 hybrid materials were prepared by hydrothermal and polymeric method, and characterized by FTIR, XRD, TEM and XPS. The gas sensitivity of PAn/SnO2 hybrid to ethanol, H2, CO and NH3 was also studied at low temperature (room temperature, 60 °C and 90 °C). It was found that An polymerized at the surface of SnO 2 and core-shell type PAn/SnO2 hybrids formed. When the operating temperature reached 90 °C, PAn/SnO2 hybrid materials had selectivity to ethanol gas, showed short response-recovery time and good reversibility, and could detect ethanol gas at a wide concentration range.

ulltRLyt.title: H2S sensitivity study of polypyrrole/WO3 materials
ulltRLyt.abstract: In this work, a H 2 S sensor formed from hybrid of WO 3 and polypyrrole (PPy) by mechanical mixing was produced. The gas-sensing properties of the hybrid materials were studied and compared with those of PPy and WO 3 . It was found that PPy/WO 3 materials can complement the drawbacks of pure PPy and WO 3 to some extent. PPy/WO 3 materials with varies PPy mass percent (1%, 3%, 5%, 10%, 20%) had better reversibility than PPy, and also had higher sensitivity than WO 3 when operated at 90 °C. The sensing mechanism of PPy/WO 3 materials to H 2 S was presumed to be the synergism of PPy and WO 3 or the effect of p–n heterojunctions.

oVQ17n7I.title: Preparation and modification of one-dimensional metal oxides
oVQ17n7I.abstract: Considerable attention has been addressed on one-dimensional metal oxides because of their unique structure and properties. Performances of the one-dimensional materials can be improved by further modification via loading, impregnation or coating method. In this review, some applications and preparation technologies of one-dimensional metal oxides are reviewed. Synthetic strategies and current progress in the modification are also commented.

rZntd4dq.title: Synthesis and gas sensing properties of α-Fe2O 3@ZnO core-shell nanospindles
rZntd4dq.abstract: α-Fe2O3@ZnO core-shell nanospindles were synthesized via a two-step hydrothermal approach, and characterized by means of SEM/TEM/XRD/XPS. The ZnO shell coated on the nanospindles has a thickness of 10-15nm. Considering that both α-Fe2O3 and ZnO are good sensing materials, we have investigated the gas sensing performances of the core-shell nanocomposite using ethanol as the main probe gas. It is interesting to find that the gas sensor properties of the core-shell nanospindles are significantly enhanced compared with pristine α-Fe2O 3. The enhanced sensor properties are attributed to the unique core-shell nanostructure. The detailed sensing mechanism is discussed with respect to the energy band structure and the electron depletion theory. The core-shell nanostructure reported in this work provides a new path to fabricate highly sensitive materials for gas sensing applications. © 2011 IOP Publishing Ltd.

8KQvnQqJ.title: Preparation, characterization and gas sensitivity of polypyrrole/γ- Fe2O3 hybrid materials
8KQvnQqJ.abstract: Polypyrrole (PPy)/γ-Fe2O3 hybrid materials were prepared by sol-gel polymerization in situ and characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM). The gas sensitivities in CO, H2, NH 3, ethanol or acetone atmospheres were determined at 30 C, 60 C and 90 C. FT-IR and XRD patterns suggest that ferric oxide in the hybrids was γ-Fe2O3, with a diameter of approximately 5 nm. TG-DTA and HRTEM analyses showed that different reactant molar ratios of pyrrole monomer: Fe(NO3)3·9H2O resulted in different microstructures of γ-Fe2O3 and molecular weights of PPy. An increased amount of Fe(NO3)3· 9H2O increased the degree of uniformity of the molecular weight of PPy and resulted in a change of γ-Fe2O3 microstructure from granular to stick particles. The results of gas sensitivities showed that the PPy/γ-Fe2O3 hybrids exhibited high sensitivity to NH3 at mild operating temperature (<100 C). Furthermore, the sensing mechanism was also discussed. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Kg3X0qX6.title: Mesoporous tin dioxide nanopowders based sensors to selectively detect ethanol vapor
Kg3X0qX6.abstract: In the paper, mesoporous SnO2 nanopowders were synthesized via a simple and mild SnCl4 hydrolysis process using cationic surfactant (cetyltrime thylammonium bromide, CTAB: CH3(CH2) 15N+(CH3)3Br-) as structure directing agent and ammonia as an alkali source at room temperature, combined with a subsequent calcination process. The products were characterized by X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiment. A gas sensor was fabricated from the as-prepared mesoporous SnO 2 nanopowders and used to test the response to different concentrations of ethanol, methanol, hexane, NH3, H2 and CO at different operating temperatures. The results showed that the mesoporous SnO2 sensor exhibited high sensitivity, good selectivity and quick response-recovery characteristics to ethanol, implying the potential application of the sensor for detecting ethanol. © 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

vNSEHfjh.title: Synthesis, characterization of Cr-doped TiO<sub>2</sub> nanotubes with high photocatalytic activity
vNSEHfjh.abstract:
Cr-doped TiO2 nanotubes (Cr/TiO2 NTs) with high photocatalytic activity were prepared by the combination of sol–gel process with hydrothermal treatment. XRD,
 TEM and UV–vis DRS techniques were employed for microstructural characterization. TEM images show that Cr/TiO2 NTs are in good tubular structure and have diameter of about 10 nm. The Cr doping induces the shift of the absorption edge
 to the visible light range and the narrowing of the band gap. The photocatalytic experiment reveals that the photocatalytic
 performance of TiO2 NTs can be improved by the doping of chromium ions.
keywords: titanium dioxide nanotubes doping chromium ions photocatalytic activity sol-gel process catalyst

VTKui0Ys.title: Amino acid-assisted one-pot assembly of Au, Pt nanoparticles onto one-dimensional ZnO microrods.
VTKui0Ys.abstract: In this contribution, a facile one-pot strategy is developed for the assembly of noble metal (Au and Pt) nanoparticles onto one-dimensional ZnO microrods using a green non-toxic reagent amino acid, lysine with two amino functional groups as the capping agent. Noble metal nanoparticles with a small size capped by lysine are formed and simultaneously anchored onto the surface of ZnO. No pre-functionalization of the ZnO support is needed, hence simplifying the synthesis and reducing the fabrication cost. Inspired by the catalytic properties of Au nanoparticles in both catalyst and sensor materials, we have examined the gas sensing performances towards ethanol detection. Obtained results demonstrate that after decoration by Au nanoparticles, the sensor shows significantly enhanced sensing performances in terms of high sensitivity, fast response and recovery, excellent reproducibility and good selectivity. The improved sensor properties are probably ascribed to the catalytic Au promoters and the Schottky barriers at the metal and semiconductor interface.

sF7iAFOT.title: Preparation, characterization of CuO/CeO2 and Cu/CeO2 catalysts and their applications in low-temperature CO oxidation
sF7iAFOT.abstract: CeO2 was synthesized via sol-gel process and used as supporter to prepare CuO/CeO2, Cu/CeO2 catalysts by impregnation method. The catalytic properties and characterization of CeO2, CuO/CeO2 and Cu/CeO2 catalysts were examined by means of a microreactor-GC system, HRTEM, XRD, TPR and XPS techniques. The results show that CuO has not catalytic activity and the activity of CeO2 is quite low for CO oxidation. However, the catalytic activity of CuO/CeO2 and Cu/ CeO2 catalysts increases significantly. Furthermore, the activity of CuO/CeO2 is higher than that of Cu/CeO2 catalysts.

NIJUIZzx.title: Synthesis and characterization of titanate and CS2-modified titanate nanotubes as well as their adsorption capacities for heavy metal ions
NIJUIZzx.abstract: CS2-modified titanate nanotubes were synthesized by tubular titanate precursor via hydrothermal method. They were characterized with XRD, EDAX, TEM and Raman spectra. Adsorption capacity of the nanotubes for heavy metal ions, such as Cu2+, Pb2+ and Ag+ ions in water were also evaluated. Compared with ordinary sorbents, the nanotubes' adsorption performance are much better. The nanotubes' adsorption capacities increase apparently after being modified by CS2, and their adsorption performance is related to the anions and pH value of the solution. The adsorption capacities of pure titanate nanotubes for Pb2+, Ag+ and Cu2+ ions are 599.37, 163.22 and 474.73 mg/g, respectively. After being modified by CS2, the adsorption capacities of the nanotubes changed to 663.37, 160.21 and 423.05 mg/g, respectively.

va6VRNzh.title: Preparation, Characterization and Photocatalytic Activities of F-doped TiO 2 Nanotubes
va6VRNzh.abstract:
F-doped TiO2 nanotubes were prepared by impregnation method. The prepared catalysts were characterized by XRD, TEM, and XPS. The photocatalytic
 activity of F-doped TiO2 nanotubes was evaluated through the photodegradation of aqueous methyl orange. The experiments demonstrated that the F-doped
 TiO2 nanotubes calcined at 300 °C possessed the best photocatalytic activity. Compared with pure TiO2 nanotubes, the doping with F− significantly enhanced the photocatalytic efficiency. The high photocatalytic activity was ascribed to several beneficial
 effects produced by F-doping: creation of oxygen vacancies, presence of Ti3+, and so on.

lAbxcf8P.title: Synthesis and characterization of CuO/TiO2 catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation
lAbxcf8P.abstract: In this paper, the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts prepared by the deposition–precipitation (DP) method were extensively investigated for CO oxidation reaction. The structural characters of the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts were comparatively investigated by TG-DTA, XRD, and XPS measurements. It was shown that the catalytic behavior of CuO/TiO 2 catalysts greatly depended on the TiO 2 -support calcination temperature, the CuO loading amount and the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts calcination temperature. CuO supported on the anatase phase of TiO 2 -support calcined at 400 °C showed better catalytic activity than those supported on TiO 2 calcined at 500 and 700 °C. Among all our investigated catalysts with CuO loading from 2% to 12%, the catalyst with 8 wt% CuO loading exhibited the highest catalytic activity. The optimum calcination temperature of the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts was 300 °C. The XRD results indicated that the catalytic activity of the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts was related to the crystal phase and particle size of TiO 2 support and CuO active component. Keywords Sol–gel method CuO/TiO 2 catalyst Low-temperature CO oxidation Deposition–precipitation method 1 Introduction CO as the major toxic air pollutant, which is usually emitted by products of combustion processes from industrial, transportation and domestic activities, is always the central issues in the environmental protection field. Many noble metal catalysts such as Pd/SnO 2 , Pt/SnO 2 , Au/MnO x , Au/α-Fe 2 O 3 and Au/Co 3 O 4 have been demonstrated to be very effective in CO oxidation [1–5] . Due to high prices and scarce of noble metal, attention has been given to search an alternative catalytic component to reduce using or even replace the noble metal. Transition metals supported on some oxides are good substitute catalysts because of their low-price and wide use. Among them, copper or copper oxide can exhibit activities per unit surface area similar to those of noble metal catalysts such as platinum [6] in CO oxidation. Moreover, TiO 2 is also an attractive support material from a practical point of view. Hence, the CuO/TiO 2 was chosen for low-temperature CO oxidation activity [7] . In this paper, we presented the catalytic studies of CuO/TiO 2 catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation. The preparation method of the catalysts and their characterization by TG-DTA, XRD, XPS were described. The catalytic activity of the catalysts with different CuO content was tested. Meanwhile the correlation between their catalytic properties and the calcination temperature of the TiO 2 -support and CuO/TiO 2 catalysts were investigated systematically. 2 Experimental 2.1 TiO 2 preparation TiO 2 -support was synthesized by the sol–gel method. A Ti-containing solution was first prepared by adding 15 ml Ti(OBu) 4 to 45 ml absolute alcohol at a volume ratio of 1/3 and stirred for 20 min to obtain a homogeneous light yellow solution. In a separate beaker, the nitric acid was added drop-wise to 15 ml distilled water and 60 ml ethanol (v/v = 1:4) until pH 1 forming a mixed solvent. The former light yellow solution was added slowly to the mixed solvent and stirred for another 30 min. Thereafter the obtained sol was aged at room temperature for 1 h. The resulting gel was dried at 80 °C in water bath for 1 h until most of the ethanol was evaporated, and then dried at 80 °C for 24 h in an oven to remove ethanol completely. The as-synthesized material was then calcined in air at 350, 400, 500, 600 and 700 °C, respectively, for 3 h. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The CuO/TiO 2 catalysts were prepared by the deposition-precipitation (DP) method. At room temperature, 0.5 g TiO 2 powders were firstly suspended in the aqueous solution of an appropriate amount of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 · 3H 2 O, then, 0.25 mol/L Na 2 CO 3 solution was gradually added to the above suspended solution until the pH of the mixed solution reached 9.0. The mixture was stirred for another 1 h, then filtered and washed with distilled water. The resulting solid was dried at 80 °C for 4 h and subsequently calcined at 350, 400, 500, 600 and 700 °C, respectively, for 3 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed on a D/MAX-RAX diffractometer operating at 40 kV and 100 mA, using Cu Kα radiation (scanning range 2 θ : 20–75°). The diffraction peaks of the crystalline phases were compared with those of standard compounds reported in the JCPDS Data File. Thermogravimetry and differential thermal analyses (TG-DTA)were performed by a ZRY-2P thermal analyser. The thermograms were recorded from ambient temperature to 1173 K at a linear heating rate of 10 K/min under nitrogen atmosphere flowing at a rate of 40 ml/min. α-Al 2 O 3 was used as reference. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed with a Perkin–Elmer PHI 5600 spectrophotometer with the Mg Kα radiation. The operating conditions were kept constantly at 187.85 eV and 250.0 W. In order to subtract the surface charging effect, the C1s peak has been fixed at a binding energy of 284.6 eV. 2.4 Measurement of catalytic activity Catalytic activity tests were performed in a continuous-flow fixed-bed microreactor. A stainless steel tube with an inner diameter of 16 mm was chosen as the reactor tube. About 100 mg catalyst power was placed into the tube. The reaction gas mixture consisting of 1 vol% CO balanced with air was passed through the catalyst bed at a total flow rate of 33.4 ml/min. A typical weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 20040 mL h −1 g −1 . After 30 min reaction, the effluent gases were analyzed online by a GC-508A gas chromatograph. The activity was expressed by the conversion of CO. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 TG-DTA analysis of TiO 2 Fig. 1 shows the DTA-TG curves of the TiO 2 -support. The DTA curve of TiO 2 showed a small endothermic peak below 140 °C, where a weight-loss occurred in its TG curve. This peak could be due to the evaporation and removal of the surface adsorbed water and ethanol. The exothermic peaks between 140 and 170 °C resulted from the burning of the organic substance n -butanol, etc. The obvious endothermic peaks between 180 and 350 °C were caused by the burning of surplus carbon. This is in agreement with the results of the activity measurements. The exothermic peak centered at 400 °C resulted from the phase transition of TiO 2 from amorphous to anatase. No obvious decalescence phenomenon was observed above 500 °C in DTA curve. This indicated that the phase transition from anatase to rutile was gradually finished, which corresponded with the XRD results. 3.2 XRD analysis of TiO 2 and CuO/TiO 2 3.2.1 XRD analysis of TiO 2 To study the influence of the crystal phase transition of titania on the catalytic activity of the catalysts, the X-ray powder diffraction was used to determine the crystal phase of titania at different temperatures. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the TiO 2 -support prepared using sol–gel process and calcined in the temperature range from 350 to 700 °C for 3 h, which demonstrated the effects of calcination temperature on the TiO 2 crystal phase. It could be found that at 350 and 400 °C the crystal phase of titania remained anatase. The result was similar to that observed by Zhang et al. [8] The crystal phase transition from anatase to rutile began to appear at 500 °C. This was in good agreement with the results of TG-DTA. The anatase–rutile transformation rate ( f ), the crystal phase and the average crystallite size of TiO 2 calcined at different temperature were summarized in Table 1 . The anatase–rutile transformation rate ( f ) was determined by using the following equation f = 1 1 + 0.8 × I A ( 1 0 1 ) I R ( 1 1 0 ) × 100 % , where I A (1 0 1) is the integral intensity corresponding to the (1 0 1) crystal face peak of anatase and I R (1 1 0) is the integral intensity corresponding to the (1 1 0) crystal face peak of rutile. The average crystallite sizes of the TiO 2 calcined at different temperature were obtained by using Scherrer’s equation. D = K λ / β cos θ , where λ is the X-ray wavelength for measurement; β the breadth of diffraction rays due to the crystallite size; θ the Bragg angle of diffraction rays and K is the constant. 3.2.2 XRD analysis of CuO/TiO 2 The XRD patterns of 8 wt% CuO/TiO 2 catalysts (TiO 2 -support was calcined at 400 °C for 3 h) calcined at different temperatures were shown in Fig. 3 . For 8 wt% CuO/TiO 2 catalyst calcined at 200 °C, the CuO peak was very weak. Bandara et al. [9] reported that it was due to the presence of noticeable amorphous CuO. For the CuO/TiO 2 catalyst calcined at 300 °C, the CuO diffraction peaks at 2 θ = 35.5° and 38.6° could be observed clearly. As the calcination temperature increased, the CuO crystalline peaks became sharper and sharper, indicating the particle size of CuO became larger and larger. The calculated average CuO crystallite size by using Scherrer’s equation was listed in Table 2 . 3.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The Cu2p and Ti2p XP spectra of CuO/TiO 2 catalysts with different CuO loading were shown in Fig. 4 . The peaks of Cu (2p3/2) and Cu (2p1/2) were centered at 935.6 and 955.6 eV, respectively. The Cu (2p3/2) and Cu (2p1/2) binding energy of the samples was slightly higher than the data of pure CuO reported by Chang et al. [10] , but it is in agreement with the results of Brian et al. [11] . According to several previous studies of the catalysts based on copper oxide, the higher binding energy was possibly caused by the interaction between TiO 2 -support and active component, resulting in the shift of the Cu binding energy [10–12] . The XPS peak intensity ratios of I Cu2p / I Ti2p as a function of CuO loading ( Fig. 5 ) were determined to identify the monolayer dispersion threshold of CuO in CuO/TiO 2 catalysts. According to Yu et al. [13] , the resulting curve can be thought of as being made up of two lines with different slopes. The point of intersection of the two lines can be regarded as the maximum dispersion capacity, i.e. the monolayer dispersion threshold. So it could be concluded that the monolayer dispersion threshold of the CuO/TiO 2 system calcined at 400 °C is about 7.3 wt% CuO loading. The CuO crystalline began to appear when the CuO loading was above 7.3 wt%, and the surface of TiO 2 was occupied by the dispersed CuO to the maximum extent. 3.4 Activity measurements Fig. 5 shows the CO conversion over the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts (TiO 2 -support was calcined at 400 °C for 3 h) with different CuO loading (2–12 wt%). For all the CuO/TiO 2 samples, the activity for CO oxidation increased with the increase of the reaction temperature. It was found that the effect of the CuO loading on the CO oxidation activity of the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts had the following order: 8 wt% > 12 wt% ≈ 10 wt% > 6 wt% ≈ 4 wt% > 2 wt%. This results indicated that increasing the CuO loading could promote the catalytic activities of the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts to some extent, but it was not always so. Among all these catalysts, the 8 wt% CuO/TiO 2 catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity and obtained complete CO conversion at 110 °C. The result agreed with the XPS measurements very well. Yu et al. [13] reported that the best catalytic effect was achieved when the amount of CuO was near the monolayer dispersion threshold, higher amount of CuO loading would have reverse effect. The similar results were reported by Friedman and Freeman [12] who pointed out that beyond a critical quantity, any additional copper loading was in the form of bulk crystalline oxide. Liu and Flytzani-stephanopoulos [14] suggested that the activity of catalyst derived primarily from the combination of finely dispersed copper-support systems, and bulk copper oxide had negligible contributions. Therefore, when the CuO loading was more than the monolayer dispersion threshold, the number of the effective active phase species was reduced with the increase of crystalline CuO, resulting in a suppression of catalytic activity. Fig. 6 gives the CO oxidation activities on 8 wt% CuO/TiO 2 catalysts (TiO 2 -support was calcined at 350 °C for 3 h) calcined at different temperature. It was found that the increase in calcination temperature of the catalysts resulted in a fluctuation of the CO oxidation activities. The CO oxidation activities of the catalysts increased by increasing the calcination temperature from 200 to 300 °C. When the catalyst was calcined at 300 °C, the highest catalytic activity was observed, and the activity began to decrease as the calcination temperature reached to 400 °C. When the calcination temperature of the catalyst reached 500 °C, the CO oxidation activities decreased considerably, no complete CO conversation was detected in the reaction temperature range of 20–200 °C. From the XRD study, it could be found that the amorphous CuO in CuO/TiO 2 catalyst was noticeable when it was calcined at 200 °C. After calcined at 300 °C, the CuO diffraction peaks could be observed clearly, and the degree of crystallinity of CuO also increased with the increase of the sintering temperature This indicated that the catalytic performances of catalysts strongly dependent on the crystal phase of CuO. This is in good agreement with the report of Haller et al. [15] . According to the XRD results, as the calcination temperature raised from 300 to 500 °C, the crystal size of CuO increased considerably. This suggested that the decrease of catalytic activity was caused by the increase of CuO crystal size. Fig. 7 displays the effect of the calcination temperature of TiO 2 -support on the catalytic activities of 8 wt% CuO/TiO 2 catalyst calcined at 400 °C for CO oxidation. The reaction temperature for 100% CO conversion was 110 and 140 °C when the TiO 2 -support was calcined at 400 and 500 °C, respectively. The catalyst with TiO 2 -support calcined at 700 °C only had 87.28% CO conversion at reaction temperature of 170 °C. This indicated that the calcination temperature of TiO 2 -support had an evidently influence on the catalytic activity of CuO/TiO 2 catalyst. The XRD results ( Fig. 3 .) showes when TiO 2 was calcined at 400 °C the titania phase completely remained anatase. However, when calcined at 500 °C the rutile phase began to appear, and the fraction of rutile phase increased with the increase of the calcination temperature of TiO 2 -support. At the same time, with the increase of calcination temperature of TiO 2 -support, the particle size of TiO 2 increased. Several previous studies [16,17] of the catalysts based on titania showed that some properties of titania might strongly depended on its polymorphic phase and particle size. Based on the above analyses, the result that the catalysts with the TiO 2 -support calcined at 400 °C showed the highest catalytic activities might be attributed to the complete anatase phase of TiO 2 -support and the smaller particle size of CuO (see Fig. 8 ). In order to test the lifetime of the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts prepared by the DP method, we carried out an investigation on the 8 wt% CuO/TiO 2 catalyst (TiO 2 was calcined at 400 °C and the catalyst was calcined at 300 °C). Fig. 9 depicts the variation of the catalytic activity of the catalyst for CO oxidation as a function of reaction time. For the test, the reaction temperature was kept at 383 K. The deactivation rate for 8 wt% CuO/TiO 2 catalyst was very low, and changed very slightly during the period of reaction until the reaction was stopped (16 h). The above result of the test demonstrated that the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts were stable. 4 Conclusion The CuO/TiO 2 catalyst was proved to be an active and stable catalyst for CO oxidation. The TiO 2 particles acted as the support and the CuO acted as the active component. The catalytic activity of the catalysts depended on some elements as follows: (1) Calcination temperature of the TiO 2 -support. The catalytic activities strongly depended on the TiO 2 -support calcination temperature. In other words, the catalytic activity was affected by the crystal phase and particle size of the TiO 2 -support. CuO supported on the TiO 2 support calcined at 400 °C showed the best catalytic activity in this study. (2) The CuO loading. The activity of CuO/TiO 2 catalysts with 8 wt% CuO loading was much higher than that of the catalysts with other CuO loadings. This might be due to the fact that 8 wt% CuO loading was near the monolayer dispersion threshold (7.3 wt%) of CuO on TiO 2 . (3) Calcination temperature of the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts. The increase in CO oxidation activity of the CuO/TiO 2 catalysts with increasing calcination temperature from 200 to 300 °C could be attributed to the fact that the CuO was fully crystallized, however, the decrease in catalytic activities with increasing calcination temperature from 300 to 500 °C could be attributed to the increase of the CuO crystalline size. LOBp0UCl.title: Synthesis and characterization of thermally stable nanotubular TiO 2 and its photocatalytic activity
LOBp0UCl.abstract: Hydrogen titanate nanotubes obtained by hydrothermal synthesis are treated with sol containing titanium. The products are characterized with transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, thermal gravimetric analysis, and Raman spectroscopy. Their photocatalytic performance is evaluated by the photocatalytic degradation rates of methyl orange in aqueous solution under UV-vis light irradiation. The results reveal that the treated nanotubes are more thermally stable and exhibit better photocatalytic performance than primary nanotubes. The treated nanotubes can keep a tubular structure when calcined at 400°C. However, their precursors collapse when they are calcined only at 300°C. The more thermally stable new functional TiO2 nanotubes can be prepared by using sol containing other elements instead of sol containing Ti in the future. © 2008 American Chemical Society.

I6Zzy9ra.title: Preparation and magnetic properties of spherical α-Fe 2O3 nanoparticles via a non-aqueous medium
I6Zzy9ra.abstract: Spherical α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles have been prepared using lauric acid as a non-aqueous medium and FeCl3· 6H2O as starting precursor. The products were characterized by means of various experimental methods. The infrared spectra indicated that the α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles are capped with laurate resulting from the reaction process. The obtained spherical α-Fe 2O3 nanoparticles with diameters of about 150 nm are polycrystalline in nature, consisting of large numbers of smaller sub-units of around 20 nm. The final α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles exhibit special magnetic properties with a small remnant magnetization of 0.09515 emu g-1 and a high coercivity of 817.5 Oe at room temperature. The experimental results suggest that the lauric acid plays an important role in determining the particle size, shape, microstructure and magnetic properties of the final α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

jf38bPm8.title: Low-temperature CO oxidation over different CuO/CeO2 catalysts
jf38bPm8.abstract: CeO2 particles with different physical properties were prepared by thermal decomposition of cerous nitrate and then used as supports for CuO/CeO2 catalysts (CuO content was 6.3% based on the CeO2 mass) prepared by impregnation method. The catalytic properties of the catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation were studied using a microreactor-GC system. The thermal decomposition temperature affected the physical properties (such as morphology, particle size, and distribution) of CeO2 particles. The loading of non-crystal CuO on the CeO2 supports was different and was the highest on the CeO2 prepared by thermal decomposition at 500°C, and the corresponding CuO/CeO2 catalysts exhibited higher activity for CO oxidation than those with CeO2 prepared by thermal decomposition at 400° and 700°C.

dg9sbL5k.title: The preparation and gas sensitivity study of polypyrrole/zinc oxide
dg9sbL5k.abstract: Polypyrrole (PPy) was prepared by chemical oxidation polymerization, analyzed by FT-IR, elemental analysis and HRTEM, and studied for gas sensitivity. It suggested that PPy had sensitivity to NH 3 , H 2 S and NO x , and showed irreversibility to NO x gas. The organic–inorganic hybrid materials PPy/ZnO with different PPy weight percents were prepared by mechanical mixing, and the sensitivity study of the materials to toxic gases NH 3 , H 2 S, NO x was carried out at different operating temperatures 30, 60, and 90 °C. It was found that PPy/ZnO materials (PPy(1%)/ZnO, PPy(3%)/ZnO, PPy(5%)/ZnO, PPy(10%)/ZnO, PPy(20%)/ZnO) had better selectivity and reversibility to NO x than pure PPy, and much lower working temperature than the reported working temperature of ZnO (about 350–450 °C). Their sensitivity increased with the increasing concentration of NO x at particular working temperature, and among them PPy(10%)/ZnO had the maximum sensitivity to NO x in the same condition. They showed no response to 1000, 1500, 2000 ppm NH 3 or H 2 S. The response mechanism of PPy/ZnO materials to NO x was discussed. Keywords Preparation Gas sensitivity Polypyrrole Zinc oxide 1 Introduction With the development of the society, the demand of mankind to living environment becomes higher and higher. The detection of polluted gases, especially toxic gas has become increasingly important. The sensing materials including inorganic or organic have been studied widely [1–14] . But both of them have particular advantages and drawbacks. The significant disadvantages of inorganic semiconductors such as SnO 2 , Fe 2 O 3 , ZnO are their high operating temperature (350–450 °C) [15,16] , which increases power consumption and reduces sensor life. Several organic semiconductors, such as polypyrrole, polyaniline, polythiophere, polyacetylene, etc., have gas sensitivity at normal temperature [7–14] . Polypyrrole is the most studied among these, but its limitations reduce the application largely. The defects such as, PPy is sensitivity to electrochemical and chemical degradation, its conductivity exhibits a long-term irreversible decay due to the irreversible attack of oxygen present in the ambient, and its long response time when it is monitored gases due to the highly ordered structure [17] . In addition, the low selectivity is the most serious problem of organic and inorganic sensing materials. To prepare the optimized properties of materials, organic–inorganic sensing materials have been developed [18–20] , considering which can complement the characteristics of pure inorganic and organic materials. Recently, the studies of organic–inorganic materials for sensors are: Komila Suri [21] studied the pressure and humidity sensitivity of polypyrrole/iron oxide; Sara Nardis [22] reported that cobalt porphyrin/tin dioxide had superior selectivity to methanol vapor than to CO; Hosono and Matsubara [23,24] synthesized PPy/MoO 3 thin film and PPy/MoO 3 pressed pellet and studied for the gas sensitivity to volatile organic compounds like formaldehyde, ethanol, toluene, benzene and so on. And these types of hybrid materials have been shown to possess small grain size and high stability in air [25,26] . But the research of this kind of materials to toxic gases is few. In this paper, we prepared PPy by chemical oxidation polymerization. Anhydrous FeCl 3 was used as oxidant. The product was analyzed by FT-IR, elemental analysis and HRTEM. PPy/ZnO materials were prepared by mechanical mixing, and studied for gas sensitivity to toxic gases NH 3 , H 2 S, NO x at low temperature. To the best of our knowledge it is the first time to study the gas sensitivity of PPy/ZnO materials. 2 Experimental 2.1 The preparation and characterizations of polypyrrole (PPy) Pyrrole (Py) monomer was distilled under reduced pressure, put in a desiccator and stored in the refrigerator to use. Polypyrrole (PPy) was prepared by chemical oxidation in nitrogen atmosphere. Ethyl ether was used as solvent, and anhydrous FeCl 3 as oxidant. The reaction equation was as follows: Ethyl ether was added to a specific amount of anhydrous FeCl 3 contained in a 100 ml round bottom flask containing a magnetic stir bar, and then few drops of distilled pyrrole were added to the stirred solution. After a reaction time of 1.5 h, the mixture was filtered and the black precipitate was obtained. The product was washed by water to pH 6, followed by ethanol, and dried in vacuum. PPy was characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) (Avatar 380 FT-IR spectrophotometer), elemental analysis (Elementar Vario EL., German), and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) (Philips T20ST). 2.2 The preparation of PPy/ZnO A series of PPy/ZnO hybrid materials recorded as PPy(1%)/ZnO, PPy(3%)/ZnO, PPy(5%)/ZnO, PPy(10%)/ZnO, PPy(20%)/ZnO, PPy(30%)/ZnO, PPy(40%)/ZnO according to different PPy mass percent were prepared by mechanical mixing using PPy and ZnO (purchased from Damao, Tianjin, the particle size was about 30 nm). 2.3 Gas sensitivity detection of PPy and PPy/ZnO materials In gas sensitivity detection, NO x (mostly NO, little NO 2 and N 2 O 4 ), H 2 S and NH 3 were selected. The sensing materials were fabricated on an aluminum tube with Au electrodes and platinum wires. A Ni–Cr alloy through the tube was used as heating filament. The sensor's voltage was measured indirectly by an external resistor in the testing circuit. The volume of the testing house was 15 L, and a fan within it was used to make a homogeneous test gas atmosphere. The gas sensitivity S was defined as S = V g / V a , where V a was the initial voltage of the sensor in clear air and V g the voltage of the sensor when it was exposed to testing gases. All experiments were carried out in a fixing humidity of 60%. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 The characterizations of PPy The FT-IR transmission spectra of PPy using KBr pellet was recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm −1 ( Fig. 1 ). The specific bands are observed at 3400, 1540, 1460, 1298, 1180, 1036, 900 and 780 cm −1 . They are close to those reported data [27,28] : stretching vibration (1540 cm −1 ) of C C bond, stretching vibration (1298 cm −1 ) of C–C bond, stretching vibration (3400 cm −1 ) of N–H bond, and bonds (1460, 1180, 1036, 900, 780 cm −1 ) of pyrrole ring. The result of elemental analysis is C: 48.35%, H: 3.63%, N: 12.94%, Cl: 14.14%, (C 4.03 H 3.63 N 0.92 Cl 0.4 ), Cl − is the doping anion in PPy. Picture 1 ((a) and (b)) is the HRTEM micrograph of PPy. From Picture (a) we can see PPy shows linear structure, which indicates that Py monomer polymerizes through α–α bond as reported. Some PPy shows the ring structure (Picture (b)), which due to the connection of head and tail of linear PPy. 3.2 The gas sensitivity detection Intrinsic PPy has no gas sensitivity, but the doped PPy has gas sensitivity and its properties depending on the dopant anion [13,14,17] . In addition, higher operating temperature (such as 90 °C) is disbennifit to the gas sensitivity of PPy, it maybe can damage the linear structure of PPy and hinder the migration of vacancy in PPy [29] . In this experiment, FeCl 3 was used as oxidant and Cl − as the doping anion in PPy at the same time. PPy exhibits gas sensitivity to NH 3 , H 2 S and NO x at room temperature, which was consistent with the report [11] . But PPy exhibits irreversibility to NO x among the three gases. This maybe that NO x can block the gas/PPy interaction sites of PPy [17] . Fig. 2 is the response curve of PPy to 2000 ppm NO x . The sensitivity ( S = V g / V a ) is about 1.50. The gas sensitivity testing of PPy/ZnO materials to NH 3 , H 2 S and NO x were monitored at 30, 60 and 90 °C, respectively. It was found that PPy/ZnO materials (PPy(1%)/ZnO, PPy(3%)/ZnO, PPy(5%)/ZnO, PPy(10%)/ZnO, PPy(20%)/ZnO) had gas sensitivity to NO x , but no gas sensitivity to 1000, 1500, 2000 ppm NH 3 or H 2 S. PPy(30%)/ZnO and PPy(40%)/ZnO had no response to the three kinds of gases in our testing conditions. It suggested that PPy/ZnO materials had better selectivity to NO x than PPy. Figs. 3–5 show the relationship of PPy/ZnO materials’ NO x sensitivity with PPy mass percent at different operating temperature. We can see that these three figures have similar change tendency. The sensitivity of PPy/ZnO materials increase with the increasing gas concentration at specific temperature, and PPy(10%)/ZnO has the maximum sensitivity to the testing gas at the same volume concentration and temperature. As an example, the response curve of PPy(3%)/ZnO to 2000 ppm NO x at different temperature is showed in Fig. 6 . The sensitivity of PPy(3%)/ZnO at 30, 60 and 90 °C is 68.71, 42.10, 33.31, respectively, which is higher than that of PPy. The response time of PPy(3%)/ZnO to NO x is within few minutes, but the recovery time is about 24 h. It suggests that PPy(3%)/ZnO has better reversibility than pure PPy in some degree though the recovery time of composite is not very short. The resistance of PPy(3%)/ZnO decreases when exposed to NO x gas, that is, PPy(3%)/ZnO material shows the properties of n-type semiconductor when exposed to reducing gas. It can be explained that PPy is a p-type semiconductor and ZnO an n-type semiconductor, so there are two competitive mechanisms within PPy/ZnO materials. Due to ZnO at high level in composites, ZnO has the decisive effect in this process when exposed to the electron donating gas NO x . But the true response mechanism of PPy/ZnO materials to NO x is under research. Figs. 7–9 show the sensitivity of PPy/ZnO materials to 1000, 1500, 2000 ppm NO x at different temperatures, respectively. From Fig. 7 , we can see that the sensitivity of PPy/ZnO materials to 1000 ppm NO x is the maximum at 90 °C. In Fig. 8 , all PPy/ZnO materials to 1500 ppm NO x also have the maximum sensitivity at 90 °C excepting that PPy(10%)/ZnO exhibits the maximum sensitivity at 30 °C. The sensitivity tendency of PPy/ZnO materials to 2000 ppm NO x at different temperature ( Fig. 9 ) is not similar as Fig. 7 or 8 , which maybe that PPy/ZnO materials showed smaller signal change during further gas measurement after several times exposure to NO x . How to ameliorate this problem is our next work. 4 Conclusions The gas sensitivity study of organic–inorganic materials is in the beginning at present. To explore new sensing materials, and explain the response mechanism and supplement the deficiencies of the present sensing materials are all the emphases in the future. In this paper, we prepared PPy and PPy/ZnO materials and studied their gas sensitivity. It is the first time to report the gas sensitivity of PPy/ZnO materials to toxic gases NH 3 , H 2 S, and NO x at low temperatures 30, 60, and 90 °C. We found that PPy/ZnO materials had superior properties than PPy and ZnO: (1) PPy/ZnO materials had better selectivity and reversibility to NO x than PPy, (2) the working temperature of PPy/ZnO materials is much lower than the reported working temperature of ZnO about 350–450 °C, (3) PPy(10%)/ZnO had the maximum sensitivity to NO x in the same condition, and (4) PPy(3%)/ZnO had higher sensitivity than PPy. Xkzjyd7B.title: Synthesis and Characterization of Titanate and CS_2-modified Titanate Nanotubes as Well as Their Adsorption Capacities for Heavy Metal Ions
Xkzjyd7B.abstract: CS_2-modified titanate nanotubes were synthesized by tubular titanate precursor via hydrothermal method.They were characterized with XRD,EDAX,TEM and Raman spectra.Adsorption capacity of the nanotubes for heavy metal ions,such as Cu2+,Pb2+ and Ag+ ions in water were also evaluated.Compared with ordinary sorbents,the nanotubes' adsorption performance are much better.The nanotubes' adsorption capacities increase apparently after being modified by CS2,and their adsorption performance is related to the anions and pH value of the solution.The adsorption capacities of pure titanate nanotubes for Pb2+,Ag+ and Cu2+ ions are 599.37,163.22 and 474.73 mg/g,respectively.After being modified by CS2,the adsorption capacities of the nanotubes changed to 663.37,160.21 and 423.05 mg/g,respectively.

BMNYQklj.title: ZnO hollow spheres: Preparation, characterization, and gas sensing properties
BMNYQklj.abstract: ZnO hollow spheres were successfully prepared by using carbon microspheres as templates and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED). A gas sensor was fabricated from the as-prepared ZnO hollow spheres and tested to different concentrations of NH 3 and NO 2 at different operating temperatures. The results showed that the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor exhibited extremely different sensing behaviors to NH 3 and NO 2 . The optimum operating temperature of the sensor was 220 °C for NH 3 and 240 °C for NO 2 , respectively. At 220 °C, the responses to 25, 50 and 75 ppm NH 3 were 7.9, 11.1 and 20.4 and the response times were as long as several minutes. At 240 °C, the responses to 10, 50 and 100 ppm NO 2 were 140.6, 172.8 and 286.8 and the corresponding response times were 31, 19 and 9 s. In addition, it is also shown that the gas sensor exhibited much higher response to NO 2 than to other gases at 240 °C, implying the good selectivity and potential application of the sensor for detecting NO 2 . Keywords ZnO Hollow sphere Sensor Response Selectivity 1 Introduction As a functional semiconductor, ZnO has been extensively studied in various applications, including field-effect transistor [1] , optical device [2] , dye-sensitized solar cell [3] , solid-state gas sensor [4] and so forth. Recent studies [5,6] have comprehensively reviewed the functional devices based on ZnO material. It has been demonstrated that both the size and shape or morphology have an influence on the properties of materials [7,8] . Therefore, numerous efforts have been paid to the synthesis of nanostructured ZnO such as nanoparticles [4] , nanowires [9] , nanobelts [10,11] , nanorods [12,13] , nanotubes [14,15] and hollow spheres [16,17] for various applications. One of the most important applications of nanostructured ZnO material is solid-state gas senor. In a previous work, Ghimbeu et al. reported that ZnO films showed higher sensitivity to NO 2 than to H 2 S at 300 °C [18] . Most of the studies [4,18–23] have examined the gas sensing properties of ZnO sensors fabricated from the above-mentioned nanostructures other than hollow spheres. Inorganic hollow spheres have found a variety of potential applications due to their unique structure [24–26] . For instance, in the area of gas sensor, many studies have proved that sensing materials with either hollow-sphere structure or porous structure could largely enhance the sensor properties [27–29] . However, to our best knowledge, no research has been reported on using ZnO hollow spheres for gas sensor applications. In this work, we mainly report on the preparation, characterization and sensing properties of ZnO hollow spheres templated by carbon microspheres. The temperature-dependent and concentration-dependent sensing behaviors of the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor to NH 3 and NO 2 are studied. Other gases were also tested to depict the selectivity of the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor. Obtained results show that the gas sensor exhibited much higher response to NO 2 than to other gases at 240 °C, implying the preferential selectivity of the sensor to NO 2 . 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Chemical reagents (from Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute) such as Zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn(CH 3 COO) 2 ·2H 2 O), dimethylformamide (DMF), glucose and absolute ethanol were all of analytical grade and were used as received without further purification. Distilled water was used throughout the experiment. 2.2 Preparation of carbon microspheres Carbon microspheres were prepared according to a reported procedure [29,30] . A clear solution containing 7.2 g of glucose and 80 mL of water was placed in a 100 mL of teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 160 °C for 4 h. The puce products were collected by centrifugation and washed with distilled water and ethanol, then dried at 80 °C in an oven overnight. 2.3 Preparation of ZnO hollow spheres In a typical synthesis, 0.33 g of Zn(CH 3 COO) 2 ·2H 2 O was dissolved in 15 mL of DMF under stirring, 0.2 g of carbon microspheres were uniformly dispersed in 25 mL of DMF by ultrasonication, then the Zn(CH 3 COO) 2 solution was added into the 25 mL of DMF at a speed of 20 s per drop. After ultrasonicating for 1 h, 2 mL of water was added into the solution, then the mixed solution was aged under ambient conditions for one day. The puce precursor was collected by centrifugation and washed with distilled water and ethanol, then dried at 40 °C in vacuum for 6 h. ZnO hollow spheres with a white color were finally obtained after the puce precursor was calcined at 450 °C for 2 h in a muffle furnace. 2.4 Sensor fabrication and measurements A proper amount of ZnO hollow spheres were slightly grinded together with several drops of water in an agate mortar. The formed slurry was coated (40–50 μm in thickness) onto an alumina tube with a diameter of 1 mm and length of 4 mm, being positioned with a pair of Au electrodes and four Pt wires on both ends of the tube. A Ni–Cr alloy coil through the tube was employed as a heater to control the operating temperature by tuning the heating voltage. Gas sensing tests were performed by a HW-30A gas sensing measurement system (HanWei Electronics Co., Ltd., Henan Province, China) at a relative humidity (RH) of 25–38%. HW-30A is a static system using atmospheric air as the interference gas. Test gases with calculated amount are introduced into the test chamber by a syringe. Two electric fans installed in the chamber are used to make test gas homogeneous. After test, the chamber was removed for test gases to diffuse away. The scheme and working principle of HW-30A gas sensing measurement system are shown in Fig. 1 . The sensor response to NO 2 (oxidative gas) and NH 3 (reductive gas) is defined as R g / R a and R a / R g , where R g is the sensor resistance in a target gas and R a is the sensor resistance in air, respectively. 2.5 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation ( λ = 1.5418 Å) in a 2 θ range of 20–80°. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were taken on a Shimadzu SS-550, 15 kV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) images were abtained by a Philips FEI Tecnai 20ST transmission electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area was tested by using a Quantachrome NOVA 2000e sorption analyzer. 3 Results and discussion The typical XRD pattern of the as-prepared ZnO hollow spheres is shown in Fig. 2 . All the diffraction peaks can be well indexed to the wurtzite hexagonal ZnO, with lattice constants a = 3.249 Å and c = 5.207 Å (JCPDS card 36-1451). No other diffraction peaks can be observed in the pattern, implying that the carbon microsphere templates were completely removed. The carbon microspheres have an average diameter of 400–500 nm estimated from the SEM image shown in Fig. 3 . Fig. 4 a and b show the SEM images of the as-prepared ZnO hollow spheres with a diameter of 200–400 nm, which is smaller than that of carbon microspheres. This implies that a large shrinkage has happened in the annealing process for removing the carbon templates and a similar result have been reported by Sun et al. [29] . Some small openings (marked by white squares) in the spheres can be seen clearly, implying the hollow structure of the spheres. Detailed information of the ZnO hollow spheres can be obtained from the TEM images and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern. From Fig. 5 a and b , it can be seen that most of the ZnO hollow spheres have a diameter in the range of 200–360 nm, in accordance with the SEM observations. The contrast difference between the brighter central part and the darker marginal part implies the hollow structure of ZnO spheres. It can also be seen that the shells of these hollow spheres are coarse with a thickness of about 25 nm. A detailed observation from Fig. 5 c shows that the shells consist of numerous nanoparticles with sizes ranging from 20 to 30 nm. The SAED pattern shown in Fig. 5 d confirms the polycrystalline structure of these hollow spheres. The BET surface area of the as-prepared ZnO hollow spheres was measured to be ca. 37 m 2 /g. Fig. 6 shows the photograph of the gas sensor. The gas sensor fabricated from the prepared ZnO hollow spheres was tested to three different concentrations of NH 3 (25, 50 and 75 ppm) and three different concentrations of NO 2 (10, 50 and 100 ppm). The operating temperatures were set as 180, 200, 220 and 240 °C for NH 3 and 220, 240, 260 and 280 °C for NO 2 , respectively. The response and recovery time is defined as the time for the sensor to reach 90% of its total change in voltage. The response curves of the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor to different concentrations of NH 3 at different operating temperatures are shown in Fig. 7 . It is clear that at each operating temperature, the response of the sensor becomes larger as the concentration of NH 3 increases. On the other hand, the response amplitude enlarges from 180 to 220 °C and shrinks at 240 °C. However, the response and recovery times are not satisfactory with values up to several minutes to all NH 3 concentrations. It seems that the sensor shows the largest responses to all NH 3 concentrations when operated at 220 °C. This is also confirmed by the curves of response versus operating temperature, shown in Fig. 8 . The curves in Fig. 8 also show that the response increases with increasing NH 3 concentration at each operating temperature. The sensing performances of the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor to different concentrations of NO 2 at various operating temperatures are shown in Fig. 9 . Compared with the curves in Fig. 7 , the most distinct characteristics of the curves in Fig. 9 are the downward trend and the fast response. On one hand, the curves ascend or descend sharply with NO 2 gas in or out. On the other hand, by comparison in Fig. 9 , it can be clearly seen that the recovery times are shortened as the operating temperature increases. Taking the curves at 240 °C for example, the response times to 10, 50 and 100 ppm NO 2 are 31, 19 and 9 s, respectively. However, the recovery times are about several minutes which are much longer than the response times. The NO 2 response versus temperature curves are shown in Fig. 10 , showing that the responses to 10, 50 and 100 ppm NO 2 reach the maximums at 240 °C, with the values of 140.6, 172.8 and 286.8, respectively. It has been reported that the ZnO nanopowder-based sensor [31] showed a maximum response of 11.0 and a response time of about 130 s at 300 °C to 25 ppm NO 2 , while our ZnO hollow-sphere sensor has a maximum response of 140.6 and a response time of 31 s at 240 °C to 10 ppm NO 2 . By comparison, it is obvious that the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor in this work exhibited more excellent performances with respect to response, response time and lower optimum operating temperature. The improved sensing properties can be related to the enhanced active surface area and easier gas diffusion induced by the hollow structure of the sensor material [28] . The sensor based on ZnO hollow spheres has a loose and porous structure compared with tightly contacted ZnO nanopowders. Thus, the target gas molecules could diffuse to both the outer and inner surfaces of the ZnO hollow spheres, leading to an improved sensitivity and a shortened response time. To further depict the sensing ability of the hollow-sphere sensor, we have also fabricated a sensor based on commercial ZnO powder and tested its NO 2 sensing performance ( Fig. 11 ) for comparison. It can be seen that the response amplitudes of the commercial powder sensor are smaller than those of the hollow-sphere sensor ( Fig. 9 ). In addition, the NO 2 responses of the powder sensor (Inset of Fig. 9 ) are nearly neglectable compared with those of hollow-sphere sensor ( Fig. 10 ). It is well known that ZnO is an n-type semiconductor and its sensing mechanism is dominated by the surface process when the operating temperature is below 400 °C [32] . As a matter of fact, due to progress achieved in recent years, the sensing mechanism of gas sensors is pervasive, but still controversial and not fully understood [33] . A popular and well accepted sensing mechanism for n-type semiconductor oxides mainly involves two aspects: the formation of electron depletion layer by oxygen species on the surface of sensor material and surface reactions between target gas molecules and oxygen species that lead to a change in sensor resistance. Adsorbed oxygen species ( O 2 − , O − and O 2− ) are formed by surface adsorbed oxygen trapping electrons from the conduction band, resulting in the formation of electron depletion layer on the surface of gas sensors [33,34] . The resistance of the sensor can be modulated by oxidative or reductive interactions between oxygen species and target gases. NO 2 is an oxidative gas, it would accept electrons through the surface reactions, increasing the width of surface charge layers [35] . Thus, the sensor resistance is increased. In contrary to NO 2 , the sensor resistance is decreased in the case of reductive NH 3 . As shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. 9 , the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor behaves contrarily to NH 3 and to NO 2 , showing that the response-recovery curves are raised to NH 3 and sunk to NO 2 . In addition, in our tests, it was found that the resistance of ZnO hollow-sphere sensor decreased upon increasing operating temperature ( Fig. 12 ). In other words, the sensor resistance or conductance was very dependent on the operating temperature. A similar phenomenon was also reported in some other studies [18,36–38] . Lee and Reedy [39] have summarized the factors that are responsible for the temperature dependence of the sensor conductance (or resistance). One important factor is the differing stabilities of oxygen species at different temperatures. Arnold et al. have demonstrated that the number of surface oxygen species is a function of temperature [38] . Another issue we would like to emphasize on is the selectivity of the prepared ZnO hollow-sphere sensor. It has been depicted that gas sensors based on semiconductor metal oxides often response to several gas species simultaneously [40] , which is highly unfavorable for practical applications. Much effort has been focused on improving the selectivity of gas sensors. A very common method arised in recent years is to fabricate doped sensor material by introducing dopants, including noble metals, metal oxides and different conduction type oxides (n or p-type) into semiconductor oxides [41–45] . This method mainly makes use of the catalytic effect of noble metals or the p–n heterojunction formed by the contacts of two different metal oxides. An alternative method is the temperature modulation technique [39,46,47] , which is based on the temperature-dependence of the sensor resistance or the different optimum operating temperatures of the sensor for different gases. Compared with the former method, the temperature modulation technique is believed to be superior with regard to low fabrication cost, easy preparation and simple sensing mechanism. As is known to all, introducing noble metals as dopants into semiconductors not only increases the fabrication cost and complexity of fabrication process but also makes it more difficult for one to access a clear sensing mechanism. Thus it is highly appealing if a gas sensor shows a good selectivity to a particular gas without any special treatments. Considering that NO 2 gas is very oxidative and unstable, it can easily adsorb onto sensor material and cause surface reactions therein. This means that the NO 2 gas has more “opportunities” to be detected by a gas sensor. Furthermore, the sensor selectivity to a particular gas is to some extent dependent on the chemical nature of gases, i.e., the ability to draw electrons for oxidative gas or release electrons for reductive gas in reaction with sensor material. Fig. 13 shows the responses of the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor to various gases at 240 °C. Obviously, the sensor exhibits a maximum response to NO 2 with a value up to 286.8, while for all other gases, the responses do not exceed 50. Thus it can be concluded that the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor has a good selectivity to NO 2 against other gases and maybe useful in exploring NO 2 gas sensors. 4 Conclusion In summary, ZnO hollow spheres mediated by carbon microspheres were synthesized and characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM and SAED. The prepared ZnO hollow spheres had a diameter of 200–400 nm and a shell thickness of about 25 nm. A gas sensor was fabricated from the as-prepared ZnO hollow spheres and tested to NH 3 , NO 2 and other gases. Obtained results showed that the ZnO hollow-sphere sensor exhibited very different behaviors to NH 3 and NO 2 . The optimum operating temperature for NH 3 is 220 °C, which is lower than that (240 °C) for NO 2 . At 220 °C, the sensor showed the maximum response to all tested concentrations of NH 3 , but the response and recovery times were as long as several minutes. Notably, the sensor showed very excellent sensing performances to NO 2 in the temperature range of 240–280 °C. At 240 °C, the responses to10, 50 and 100 ppm NO 2 were 140.6, 172.8 and 286.8, while the response times were 31, 19 and 9 s, respectively. Furthermore, it is also shown that the gas sensor possessed an excellent selectivity to NO 2 against other gases at 240 °C, implying the potential of the sensor for detecting NO 2 . However, further effort is in great need and in progress for developing a gas sensor with an exclusive selectivity for NO 2.
