drfOIofY.title: Synthesis, characterization of CuO/Ce0.8Sn0.2O2 catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation
drfOIofY.abstract: Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 mixed oxide was synthesized by a co-precipitation method and used as a support for a series of CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, XPS and H 2 -TPR. Their catalytic properties were studied by using a microreactor-GC system. The results indicated that the CuO loadings and calcination temperature had a large influence on the catalytic activity of the catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation. The catalyst with 7 wt% CuO loading calcined at 650 °C for 4 h exhibited the highest catalytic activity. Combined with the XRD, XPS and TPR results, we suggest that the surface copper species and the synergetic effect in the system of Cu–Ce–Sn–O are responsible for the catalytic activity of the catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation. Keywords CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts Co-precipitation method Low-temperature CO oxidation 1 Introduction Catalytic oxidation of carbon monoxide to carbon dioxide is one of the effective treatments in environmental pollution control. Many studies have shown that noble metal catalysts have high catalytic activities for low-temperature CO oxidation [1–8] . However, the high cost and their sensitivity to sulfur poisoning have limited their application and stimulated the search for substitute catalysts [9–11] . In recent years, the studies of CO oxidation have been focused on transition metal oxides. Copper oxide catalysts, such as CuO/CeO 2 [12,13] and CuO–CeO 2 –ZrO 2 [14] , exhibited favorable catalytic activities. CeO 2 is known to be used for increasing the thermal stability of the metal oxide support, promoting low-temperature water–gas shift [15] and stabilizing the noble metal dispersion. The high oxygen storage capacity (OSC) of cerium is the most important property. Its redox couple Ce 4+ /Ce 3+ makes more oxygen available for the oxidation reactions [16] . However, pure CeO 2 is reported to have poor thermal stability [17] . To improve the property of ceria, zirconia is widely used in ceria-related catalysts. The ceria–zirconia mixed oxides have shown better resistance to thermal ageing, and better redox property compared to pure CeO 2 [18–20] . SnO 2 has been widely used as an oxidation catalyst as it can reversibly undergo the Sn 4+ ↔ Sn 2+ reaction at relatively lower temperature [21,22] . Many workers have studied the mixed oxides systems of CeO 2 and SnO 2 . Sasikala et al. [22] have researched the reduction behavior of Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 and Ce 0.3 Sn 0.7 O 2 and observed that the reduction of the mixed oxides at low temperature was improved obviously compared to the constituent oxides. Recently, Chen et al. [23] have studied the catalytic behavior of the CuO/Ce x Sn 1− x O 2 catalysts and concluded that incorporating Sn into CeO 2 could improve the redox properties of the catalysts for the selective oxidation of CO. In this work, the Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 mixed oxide was prepared via a co-precipitation method using Ce(NO 3 ) 3 · 6H 2 O and SnCl 2 · 2H 2 O and used as a support for CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts. The catalysts were characterized by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR). The effects of CuO loadings and calcination temperature on the catalytic activity were also investigated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 mixed oxide was prepared by co-precipitation. Cerium nitrate (Ce(NO 3 ) 3 · 6H 2 O) and tin chloride dihydrate (SnCl 2 · 2H 2 O) were dissolved in a dilute HCl solution to give the final concentrations of 0.08 mol/L Ce(NO 3 ) 3 · 6H 2 O and 0.02 mol/L SnCl 2 · 2H 2 O. Then 2 mol/L NH 3 · H 2 O was added to the above solution under vigorous stirring until pH was 9. The solution was centrifuged and washed with deionized water and ethanol alternatively until Cl − could not be examined by 0.1 mol/L AgNO 3 aqueous solution. The sample was dried at 80 °C for 12 h, and then calcined at 650 °C for 4 h in air. The CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method using an aqueous solution of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 · 3H 2 O and the prepared Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 support. The samples were dried overnight at 80 °C and then calcined at 400, 500, 650 and 800 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace. The CuO loadings were 1, 4, 7, 10, 15 and 20 wt%. For comparison, 7 wt% CuO/CeO 2 and 7 wt% CuO/SnO 2 catalysts were also prepared in a similar manner. 2.2 Catalysts characterization X-ray power diffraction (XRD) analyses were examined on a D/MAX-2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 100 mA) and scanning in the region 2 θ = 20–90°. Diffraction peaks of crystalline phases were compared with those of standard compounds reported in the JCPDS Data File. The particle sizes were calculated using Debye–Scherrer formula. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer with Al Kα X-ray source ( hν = 1486.6 eV), hybrid (magnetic/electrostatic) optics and a multi-channel plate and delay line detector (DLD). All binding energies (BE) were referenced to the adventitious C1s line at 285 eV. The atomic ratio on the surface of the sample was calculated. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiment was carried out under a mixed gas flow rate of 5% H 2 in N 2 . The flow rate was 20 mL min −1 over 0.05 g catalyst. The catalyst bed was heated to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C min −1 . Prior to TPR, the samples were treated in air at room temperature for 30 min. The H 2 uptake amount during the reduction was measured by using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement All catalytic activity tests of CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts were performed in a continuous fixed-bed flow microreactor, using 200 mg catalyst powder. The air flow rate was 33.3 mL/min and the CO gas flow rate was 3.3 mL/min. The reaction temperature was measured using a thermocouple projecting into the catalyst bed. The space velocity ( F / W ) was 11,000 mL h −1 g −1 . The effluent gases were analyzed online by a GC-900A gas chromatography with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts with various CuO loadings calcined at 650 °C for 4 h. For comparison, the XRD pattern of CuO/CeO 2 catalyst is also shown in Fig. 1 . The diffraction peaks at 2 θ 28.5°, 33.1° and 47.5° in the XRD patterns of all the samples corresponded to the cubic fluorite structure of CeO 2 . However, weak SnO 2 peaks at 2 θ 26.5° and 51.8° were also observed. Sasikala et al. [22] have reported that the low intensity of SnO 2 peaks was due to its poor crystallinity. The particle sizes of the supports of 7 wt% CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 and 7 wt% CuO/CeO 2 were about 12.61 and 17.31 nm. Due to the fact that the ionic radius of Sn 4+ (0.71 Å) was smaller than that of Ce 4+ (1.03 Å), the grain size of CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 was smaller than that of CuO/CeO 2 . This may indicate that most of SnO 2 is incorporated into the cell of CeO 2 . Furthermore, we could find from Fig. 1 that there was no visible reflection characteristic of CuO crystal phase when CuO loading was lower than 7 wt%, which indicated that CuO was well dispersed on the surface of Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 . But when CuO loading exceeded 7 wt%, the reflections attributed to CuO (2 θ = 35.5°, 38.7°) appeared, indicating the formation of bulk CuO phase. The intensity of the peaks became stronger and stronger when the CuO loading increased from 10 to 20 wt%, which may be due to the aggregation of bulk CuO on the surface of the support. The XRD patterns of 7 wt% CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts calcined at different temperatures for 4 h are presented in Fig. 2 . It could be seen that there were no peaks assigned to CuO crystal phase when the calcination temperature was below 650 °C, indicating that CuO was well dispersed on the surface of Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 . However, when the calcination temperature increased to 800 °C, we could find two small peaks characteristic of CuO at 2 θ = 35.5°, 38.7°. In addition, as the calcination temperature increased, the peaks became narrower and sharper, indicating that the particle sizes of CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts became larger and larger. To analyze the surface composition and elemental oxidation states, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed and the XPS spectra of O 1s, Ce 3d, Cu 2p and Sn 3d of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . From Fig. 3 a, we could find that O 1s spectrum contained two main peaks. The peak of higher binding energy at 531.3 eV was assigned to the absorbed oxygen, while the peak of lower binding energy at 529.8 eV was assigned to lattice oxygen. The Ce 3d XPS spectrum presented six peaks at about 916.2, 907.5, 900.4, 899.3, 888.3 and 882.2 eV as shown in Fig. 3 b. This is in agreement with the result reported by Zhang et al. [24] , which indicated that the valence of cerium in the mixed oxide was +4. There were no peaks assigned to Ce 3+ in Fig. 3 b. Fig. 3 c presents the XPS spectrum of Cu 2p. The peaks of Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2 were centered at 933.6 and 952.8 eV, respectively. Kundakovic and Flytzani-Stephanopoulos [25] reported that the binding energy of 933.0–933.8 eV for the Cu 2p 3/2 and the shake-up peaks were characteristic of CuO, while to lower binding energy (932.2–933.1 eV) and the absence of shake-up peaks were characteristic of reduced copper species. The presence of the main peak at 933.6 eV and the satellite peak indicate that the copper species in the catalysts is CuO. The Sn 3d spectrum of the samples is shown in Fig. 3 d. The peaks centered at 486.2 and 494.6 eV represent the spectra of Sn 3d 5/2 and Sn 3d 3/2 , which are assigned to SnO 2 [26,27] . The surface composition of the catalysts was also studied by XPS. The results showed that the atomic ratio of Cu/(Cu + Sn + Ce) (0.24) on the surface was considerably higher than that in the bulk (0.14) of the catalyst, which indicated that the copper oxide species were highly dispersed on the surface of the catalysts. This is in good agreement with XRD analysis. H 2 -TPR profile of the CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalyst calcined at 650 °C for 4 h is shown in Fig. 4 . Rao et al. [28] reported that pure CuO showed a single reduction peak at 380–392 °C and pure CeO 2 showed two reduction peaks at 500 and 800 °C. While CuO supported on CeO 2 showed a two-step reduction at much lower temperatures due to the fact that finely dispersed CuO strongly interacted with ceria (130–175 °C) and larger CuO particles weakly associated with ceria (180–200 °C). From Fig. 4 , two reduction peaks at about 158.4 and 243.3 °C in the low-temperature region and a broad reduction peak at 496.9 °C could be obviously observed. Based on the above reports, the peak at 158.4 °C can be attributed to the reduction of CuO finely dispersed on the surface of support and the peak at 243.3 °C to the reduction of bulk CuO and Sn 4+ species on the surface of supports. The peak at 496.9 °C can be assigned to the reduction of bulk SnO 2 and surface Ce 4+ and the peak at 810.5 °C is due to the high temperature reduction of bulk CeO 2 [29] . 3.2 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic activities of the catalysts with various CuO loadings are shown in Fig. 5 . It could be seen from Fig. 5 that the light-off temperatures for 110% CO conversion ( T 100 ) of all the catalysts were below 100 °C. However, the catalytic activities of pure CuO and Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 were much lower (not shown in Fig. 5 ). This indicates that there is a synergistic effect between CuO and Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 , which is responsible for the high CO oxidation catalytic activity. The T 100 of the catalysts with 1, 4, 7, 10, 15 and 20 wt% CuO loading were about 110, 100, 75, 75, 75 and 110 °C, respectively. Chen et al. [23] have reported the CuO/Ce x Sn 1− x O 2 catalysts for selective oxidation of CO and pointed out that the T 100 of the 7 wt% CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalyst was 90–95 °C. In our present condition, we could find that the optimum CuO loading was 7 wt% and the T 100 was 75 °C, which exhibited the highest catalytic activity. When CuO loading was below 7 wt%, the catalytic activity increased with the increase of CuO loading. But when CuO loading was higher than 7 wt%, the catalytic activity did not increase and even decreased, which may be due to the formation of bulk CuO. This is in good agreement with the XRD results. The above results indicate that the CuO loading has much influence on the catalytic activity of the samples. When CuO loading is in an appropriate region, it can promote the oxidation of CO. However, when CuO loading exceeds a definite value, the additional copper forms bulk CuO, which has a reverse effect on the catalytic activity [30] . For comparison, Fig. 6 shows the catalytic activities of CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 , CuO/CeO 2 and CuO/SnO 2 catalysts with 7 wt% CuO loading for low-temperature CO oxidation. From Fig. 6 , it could be found that the CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalyst displayed the highest catalytic activity ( T 100 = 75 °C), while the catalytic activity of CuO/SnO 2 catalyst was the lowest, which could not reach 100% conversion until the temperature increased to 190 °C. The T 100 of CuO/CeO 2 catalyst was 120 °C. The results indicate that incorporating Sn into CeO 2 can promote the redox properties. This is probably because there is a synergetic effect in Ce–Sn mixed oxide, the effect can enhance the reducibility of Ce 4+ to Ce 3+ , and therefore decrease the conversion temperature of CO oxidation. Fig. 7 shows the catalytic activities of 7 wt% CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts calcined at different temperatures for 4 h. From Fig. 7 , it was clear that the catalytic activities increased with the increase of the calcination temperatures from 400 to 650 °C. The catalyst calcined at 650 °C exhibited the highest catalytic activity and the T 100 of the catalyst was 75 °C. When the calcination temperature increased to 800 °C, the catalytic activity decreased. This may be due to the sintering of the CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalyst at high temperature and the formation of bulk CuO, which may have a negative effect on the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions The CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation and tested for the CO oxidation at low temperature. From the experimental results, the following conclusions can be summarized: (1) The XRD and TPR results showed that the catalytic activities of the catalysts depended on the finely dispersed copper oxide on the surface of the support. The XPS analysis indicated that the valence of cerium in the mixed oxide was +4, and the copper species in the catalysts was CuO. Furthermore, XPS analysis also indicated that the copper oxide species was enriched on the surface of the support. (2) From the catalytic activity tests, we could see that the catalytic behavior of CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 system was obviously influenced by CuO loading and the calcination temperature. The CuO (7 wt%)/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalyst calcined at 650 °C for 4 h exhibited the highest catalytic activity among all of the prepared catalysts. Moreover, the study results showed that the catalytic activity of the CuO/Ce 0.8 Sn 0.2 O 2 catalyst for low-temperature CO oxidation was higher than that of CuO/CeO 2 and CuO/SnO 2 . This might be due to the synergetic effect in Ce–Sn mixed oxide, which enhanced the reducibility of the catalysts. h1rPJSYQ.title: Porous α-Fe2O3 hollow microspheres and their application for acetone sensor
h1rPJSYQ.abstract: Porous α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres were synthesized through a simple and efficient carbon sphere template method. The samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy and N 2 adsorption–desorption. Structural characterization indicated that as-prepared α - Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres had porous structure with around 200 nm in diameter and thin shell about 10 nm thick. The average pore size and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller specific surface area of α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres were 6.5 nm and 111.6 m 2 /g, respectively. The gas sensing behavior investigation showed that as-synthesized α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres exhibited very good gas sensing property to acetone vapor. Graphical Abstract HRTEM images of the α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres. Keywords Acetone sensor α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres Synthesis Characterization 1 Introduction As an environmentally friendly n-type semiconductor, α-Fe 2 O 3 has been proven to be a good gas sensitive material for detection of toxic, combustible, explosive and harmful gases in both domestic and industrial applications. Extensive studies have been done to improve the gas sensing performances of the α-Fe 2 O 3 based sensor, such as adding promoters, doping additives, decreasing grain size, controlling pore and surface defects, etc. [1] . It is well-known that the shape and size of α-Fe 2 O 3 have a significant influence on its gas sensing properties. α-Fe 2 O 3 nanostructures with different morphologies have been successfully synthesized, including nanorods [2,3] , nanotubes [4] , nanowires [5] and hollow microspheres [6–8] . Some recent research has indicated that using carbon microspheres as templates to synthesize hollow microspheres is a simple but efficient approach. Up-to-date, several metal oxides, including WO 3 , Ga 2 O 3 , SnO 2 , TiO 2 , had been fabricated through carbon sphere template process [9,10] . As a novel green template, in comparison with polymer or silica microspheres, carbon microspheres have one apparent feature: there are a number of hydroxyl groups (–OH) on the surface, which makes surface modification unnecessary. As a chemical reagent, acetone is extensively applied in industry, but its easy volatilization and toxic nature make it dangerous to people at high concentration in air. It may cause a headache, fatigue, nausea, even narcosis and death with the concentration of acetone in air higher than 1000 ppm. High concentration acetone vapor will also have a bad influence on the function of kidney and liver. Thus, detecting and measuring acetone in the workplace is necessary for human’s safety and health. In addition, acetone has been related to diabetes. The medical reports show that the average concentration of acetone in the breath products exhaled by diabetic patients and their blood is higher than that of healthy people [11,12] . The validity of acetone detection for diabetes diagnostics has been supported by extensive medical researches [13,14] . Therefore, sensor may be one of the most promising methods in measuring the concentration of acetone, due to its simplicity, precision and convenience. In this paper, we develop a simple and efficient template approach to fabricate α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres using carbon microspheres as templates and investigate the gas sensing behavior of the α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres towards acetone vapor. 2 Experimental All chemicals in this work were of analytical grade and were used as received without further purification. 2.1 Preparation of carbon microspheres Carbon microspheres were prepared in a typical procedure. 7.2 g glucose was dissolved in 80 ml distilled water to get a clear solution and then hydrothermal treatment at 160 °C for 6 h. The precipitate was centrifuge-rinsed with distilled water and ethanol for several times till getting the clear solution, and then dried at 80 °C in air for 12 h. 2.2 Preparation of porous α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres The synthesis process of porous α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres was as follows: 0.5030 g carbon microspheres were uniformly dispersed in 100 ml N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) by ultrasonication for 1 h. 0.1610 g Fe(NO 3 ) 3 ·9H 2 O dissolved in 20 ml DMF was slowly dropped into the above mixture and then 20 drops of distilled water were added, followed by ultrasonication for 1 h. The mixed solution was aged under ambient temperature for 24 h. The resulting precursor was centrifugated and washed with distilled water and ethanol, then dried at 80 °C in air for 12 h. After calcined at 450 °C in air for 2 h, the product was cooled to room temperature, and red α-Fe 2 O 3 powders were obtained. 2.3 Sample characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was performed on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer, with Cu K α radiation at 40 kV and 100 mA in a scanning range 3–80° (2 θ ). The diffraction peaks of the crystalline phase were compared with those of standard compounds reported in the JCPDS Date File. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer with the Al K α X-ray source ( hv =1486.6 eV), hybrid (magnetic/electrostatic) optics and a multi-channel plate and delay line detector (DLD). In order to subtract the surface charging effect, the C1s peak was fixed, in agreement with the literature, at a binding energy of 284.6 eV. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Shimadzu SS-550, 15 kV) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, Philips FEI Tecnai 20ST, 200 kV) were carried out to observe the morphologies of the sample. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were collected at liquid nitrogen temperature using a Quantachrome NOVA 2000e sorption analyzer. The specific surface area ( S BET ) of the sample was calculated following the multi-point Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) procedure. The pore-size distribution was determined from the adsorption branch of the isotherms using the Barett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. 2.4 Fabrication of the gas sensor and measurement of the sensing performance Alumina substrate tube 4 mm long was used for the heater and sensing base. α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow sphere powders were mixed with distilled water, and then were coated onto alumina tube attached with Pt electrodes. The schematic diagram of a typical gas sensor is shown in Scheme 1 . The gas sensing behavior was investigated by using the commercial gas-sensing measurement system of HW-30A. The sensor signal was recorded by a computer at a constant test voltage of 5 V. The operating temperature was controlled by tuning the heating voltage. The sensor response was calculated as the ratio R air / R vap , where R air and R vap are the resistance values of the sample in air and in the presence of acetone vapor, respectively. The response and recovery times were obtained by the time for 90% of full response or 90% of full recovery of the response. 3 Results and discussion A rational mechanism of the formation of α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres is described in Scheme 2 . Because as-prepared carbon microspheres had plenty of hydroxyl groups (–OH) on the surface, Fe 3+ cations can be absorbed onto the surface of carbon microspheres and bind to the surface hydroxyl groups. Then Fe 3+ further hydrolyzed to form Fe 2 O 3 · x H 2 O shell on the surface of the carbon microspheres, the presence of small amount water can promote the hydrolysis reaction, forming a core–shell structure. During calcination the aggregation of Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles resulted in the formation of the pores in shell and the carbon microspheres were removed in the form of carbon dioxide which could escape through the pores [15] . XRD was used to identify the crystal phase of the sample. Fig. 1 shows the XRD pattern of the as-prepared product. It is clear that all the diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern can be readily indexed as α-Fe 2 O 3 (JCPDS file no. 33–664), and size-broadening of the reflection peaks can be observed. No characteristic reflection peaks from other Fe species can be detected in the sample. The mean crystallite size is 6.7 nm, determined using Scherrer’s equation from (110) diffraction peak of α-Fe 2 O 3 . SEM analyses were performed to examine the morphology of the sample. Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of as-prepared α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres. As shown, SEM overview observation reveals that as-prepared α-Fe 2 O 3 products consist of spherical microstructures with the diameter of around 200 nm. The outer surfaces of the microspheres are rough, indicating that they are composed of a large number of loosely packed nanoparticles. Close observation reveals that there is partial cave-in on the surface of some microspheres, indicating the hollow core of the sample and thin shell wall. To further investigate the structure of α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres, the sample was characterized by HRTEM. Fig. 3 displays the TEM images of the hollow microspheres and the electron diffraction pattern. The strong contrast between the dark edges and pale centers in these images confirms the hollow structure of the α-Fe 2 O 3 microspheres, with thin shell about 10 nm thick. It can also be clearly observed that the shell is composed of a large number of very small nanoparticles and constitutes a porous framework. The corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres further reveals that the hollow microspheres are composed of α-Fe 2 O 3 polycrystallites. XPS analysis was used to study the surface compositions of the product. As seen in Fig. 4 a, the wide XPS picture of the product shows that no peaks of other elements except C, Fe and O were observed in the picture, indicating that the product consists of Fe and O. The calculated atomic ratio of Fe and O by XPS is approximately 1:4, which is much lower than that (1:1.5) in α-Fe 2 O 3 , suggesting that as-prepared α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres possess the excess oxygen and the enhanced oxygen adsorption capability. Fig. 4 b shows the high-resolution XPS of Fe 2 p . The binding energies of Fe 2 p 3/2 and Fe 2 p 1/2 are centered at 710.6 and 724.4 eV, respectively, with an energy separation between the spin–orbit doublet of 14 eV, indicating the existence of the oxidation state of Fe 3+ [16] . As shown in Fig. 4 c, the O 1 s spectrum is broad, complex and exhibits four peaks. There exists two types of crystal lattice oxygen species on the sample, and the binding energies are 528.1 and 530.0 eV, respectively. Peak at 530.0 eV is in good agreement with crystal lattice oxygen in α-Fe 2 O 3 bonded to Fe 3+ [17] . The origin of peak at 528.1 eV is obscure. It is suggested that the peak at 528.1 eV may root in the crystal lattice oxygen bonded to both Fe 3+ and H + (Fe–O–H). The different in electronegative between Fe 3+ and H + influences their bonding state with O 2− , which results in the shift in O 1 s energy level and the decrease in binding energies. As can be seen, there also exists two types of chemisorbed oxygen species. The binding energies are around 531.9 and 533.4 eV, respectively. It is well known that position of the signal of O 1 s of the adsorbed oxygen relies on the charge state of adsorbed oxygen [18] . Peak at 531.9 eV is attributed to adsorbed O − species on the surface of α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres, and peak at 533.4 eV is attributed to chemisorbed O 2 − species on the surface. The surface area and porosity of the α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres were investigated by means of Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis and nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms. Because the α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres are composed of a large number of nanoparticles, a high surface area can be expected, which is proven by BET analysis. The BET specific surface area is 111.6 m 2 /g. Fig. 5 a and b shows the N 2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution of α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres. A distinct hysteresis loop can be observed between adsorption and desorption branch, indicating porous structure of α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres. The plot of the pore size distribution reveals that the porous hollow microspheres with a size distribution of 1–20 nm and centered at 2.5 nm. The α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres have an average pore diameter of 6.5 nm. Acetone gas sensing measurements were carried out at different operating temperatures and different acetone vapor concentrations in air. To determine the optimal operating temperature to detect acetone vapor, the sensor working temperature was varied from 50 to 450 °C. As seen in Figs. 6 and 7 , the operating temperature has a great influence on the acetone vapor response and on the dynamic behavior of the response. Fig. 6 reports the response of the sensor to 100 ppm acetone vapor as a function of operating temperature. The sensor response is observed to be poor when the operating temperature is below 200 °C, while the sensor response is very good when the operating temperature is above 250 °C, and the response reaches a maximum value at the operating temperature of 350 °C. However, the sensor response is observed to degrade when the operating temperature is higher than 400 °C. As mentioned earlier, the α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres are porous and possess a large amount of chemisorbed oxygen species ( O 2 − and O − ) on the surface. The large specific surface and the increasing effective adsorption sites on the surface result in the improved sensing property. When the α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres are exposed to the reducing gas like acetone vapor, the acetone vapor reacts with the chemisorbed oxygen species, which induces that the electrons are released back to the conduction band, accompanied with a decrease in resistance [19] . It is well known that the change in resistance of semiconducting oxide gas sensors is primarily caused by adsorption and desorption of gas molecules on the surface of the sensor [20] . Therefore, it is suggested that the sensing behavior of the sensor not only relies on the interaction of acetone vapor molecules with chemisorbed oxygen species, but rather on the adsorption of the acetone vapor molecules on the surface and the desorption of the products. At lower temperature, the reaction products do not get readily desorbed from the sensor surface. The species cover the sensing sites on the sensor surface, which prevents the further reaction between acetone vapor and chemisorbed oxygen. Subsequently, no appreciable change in the resistance of the sensor is observed, so the resistance of the sensor decreases little, resulting in the lower response. As increase in the operating temperature the reaction products are readily desorbed, giving sensing sites on the sensor to react with new gas species, resulting in the higher response. However, when the operating temperature is higher than the optimal temperature, the acetone is difficult to be adsorbed, resulting in less acetone vapor reacting with chemisorbed oxygen. Therefore, the response decreases. Fig. 7 depicts the response and recovery characteristics curves versus operating temperature to 100 ppm acetone vapor. The response and recovery times are found to be dependent upon the operating temperature. The response times are very fast, lower than 5 s, at all operating temperature except 250 °C (17 s). In contrast, the recovery times are relatively long and become longer with increasing the operating temperature, however, the values of recovery times lie within 30 s. Fig. 8 shows the response of α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres based sensor as a function of the acetone vapor concentration at the optimal working temperature of 350 °C. As can be observed, the response increases significantly with increasing the acetone vapor concentration from 10 to 1000 ppm. The increase in the gas concentration implies a large surface coverage, resulting in an increase in the surface reaction between the surface adsorbed oxygen species and the vapor molecules. The chemisorbed negative oxygen ions on the sensor surface can react with acetone to release electrons, and with the increase in vapor concentrations more electrons may be released to the surface of sensor, resulting in an increase in response. However, the response slowly increases with increase in the acetone vapor concentrations above 1000 ppm, which indicates that the sensor response exhibits more or less saturation of the surface coverage of vapor molecules. The similar behavior has been observed by other groups [19,21] . Fig. 9 shows the response and recovery characteristic curves for different concentrations of acetone vapor at the operating temperature of 350 °C. As seen from Fig. 9 , the response is very fast and the response times are within 5 s after exposed to different concentrations of acetone vapor. However, the recovery is not as quick as the response, and the recovery time increases with increasing acetone vapor concentrations. Fortunately, the recovery time does not exceed 30 s even the vapor concentrations up to 4000 ppm. 4 Conclusions In summary, porous α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres were synthesized through a simple and efficient carbon microsphere template method. The samples were characterized by XRD, XPS, SEM, TEM and N 2 adsorption–desorption. Structural characterization indicates that as-prepared α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres have porous structure with around 200 nm in diameter and about 10 nm in shell thick. The average pore size and BET surface area of hollow microspheres are 6.5 nm and 111.6 m 2 /g, respectively. The acetone gas sensing behavior investigation shows that as-synthesized α-Fe 2 O 3 hollow microspheres exhibit very good response to acetone vapor. 8YnrxklS.title: The preparation and characterization of la doped TiO2 nanotubes and their photocatalytic activity
8YnrxklS.abstract: La-doped TiO2 nanotubes (La/TiO2 NTs) were prepared by the combination of sol-gel process with hydrothermal treatment. The prepared samples were characterized by using transmission electron microscopy, x-ray diffraction, x-ray photoelectron spectra, and ultraviolet-visible spectra. The photocatalytic performance of La/TiO2 NTs was studied by testing the degradation rate of methyl orange under ultraviolet (UV) irradiation. The results indicated La/TiO2 NTs calcined at 300°C consisted of anatase as the unique phase. The absorption spectra of the La/TiO2 NTs showed a stronger absorption in the UV range and a slight red shift in the band gap transition than that of pure TiO2 nanotubes. The photocatalytic performance of TiO2 NTs could be improved by the doping of lanthanum ions, which is ascribed to several beneficial effects the formation of Ti-OLa bond and charge imbalance, existing of oxygen defects and Ti3+ species, stronger absorption in the UV range and a slight red shift in the band gap transition, as well as higher equilibrium dark adsorption of methyl orange. 0.75 wt% La/TiO2 NTs had the best catalytic activity. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

xJpMsGHg.title: Preparation and Gas Sensing Properties of Gamma Iron Oxide Nanopowders by Microemulsion Method
xJpMsGHg.abstract: γ-Fe_2O_3 nanopowders were synthesized from the two microemulsion solutions,such as NaOH/ DBS/C_6H_5CH_3/H_2O and NaOH/CTAB/CHCl_3/CH_3CH_2CH_2OH/H_2O,and their gas sensing properties were studied.The products were characterized by means of FT-IR,XRD and TEM.The results indicate that spheri- calγ-Fe_2O_3 nanoparticles with a particle size of about 4～5 nm can be obtained from the two microemulsion solutions,when DBS and CTAB were used as surfactant and the ratios of W/O were 10.77 and 10.56, respectively.The small particle size can be attributed to the remanant surfactants adsorbed onγ-Fe_2O_3 nano- particles which prevent the aggregation ofγ-Fe_2O_3 nanoparticles.The sensors,made fromγ-Fe_2O_3 nanopow- ders obtained from the two microemulsion solutions,have high sensitivities of 12.5 for DBS and 23.8 for CTAB to 0.1% ethanol,as well as show short response-recovery time to 0.1% ethanol,that is,20 and 30 s for DBS and 15 and 47 s for CTAB,respectively.Both of them can meet the requirements of practical applications and are promising ethanol sensors due to their sensitivities and good linear relations to the concentration.

zvehOcUN.title: TiO Supported Nano—Au Catalysts Prepared via Solvated Metal Atom Impregnation for Low-Temperature CO Oxidation
zvehOcUN.abstract: TiO2 supported nano-Au catalysts were prepared by solvated metal atom impregnation (SMAI) method. The catalysts were characterized by means of AAS, TPD, H2 reduction desorption (H2-RD), XRD, TEM, XPS and tested for low-temperature CO oxidation. XRD and TEM results showed that the pretreatment temperature had an influence on the particle size of Au/ TiO2 catalysts. The average particle size increased with the increase in pretreatment temperature. XPS indicated that gold in the catalysts was presented in the form of metallic state clusters. Catalytic studies showed these catalysts were very active and stable in low-temperature CO oxidation. The CO oxidation activity of the catalysts increased as the Au particle size decreased. The measurement results of AAS, TPD and H2-RD revealed that there were some organic fragments on the surface of Au particles which might be responsible for the high stability of the Au/TiO2 catalysts.

uXcMmmsU.title: Hydrothermal fabrication of various morphological α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles modified by surfactants
uXcMmmsU.abstract: Two kinds of various morphological α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles modified by anionic surfactant (sodium dodecylsulfonate, SDS) and cationic surfactant (hexadecyipyridinium chloride, HPC), respectively, have been synthesized via hydrothermal method, using simple inorganic salt (NH 4 ) 3 Fe(C 2 O 4 ) 3 and alkali NaOH as starting precursors. Meanwhile, α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles without surfactant are also fabricated under the same conditions for comparison. The resultant products were characterized by means of Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron micrograph (TEM) combined with electron diffraction (ED) and magnetization measurements. It is interesting that the obtained α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles without surfactant are polyhedral with average particle size of 90 ± 35 nm; while the obtained α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles modified by SDS are ellipsoidal with mean particle size of major axis: ca. 420 nm; minor axis: ca. 205 nm and those modified by HPC are spherical with mean particle size of ca. 185 nm observed from TEM. In addition, magnetic hysteresis measurements reveal that the α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles modified by two surfactants show enhancement in coercivity ( H c ) and the remanent magnetization ( M r ) compared with those of the obtained α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles without surfactant at room temperature. The experimental results suggest that the surfactants not only significantly influence the size and shape of the particles, but also their magnetic properties. Keywords A. Nanostructures B. Chemical synthesis C. X-ray diffraction D. Magnetic properties 1 Introduction The motivation for the fabrication of various morphology and size of α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles was driven by the strong interest in their novel properties and potential applications in red pigments, catalysts, ceramic, anticorrosive agents and gas sensors [1–8] . Till now, several synthetic methods have been developed for preparation of α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles including sol–gel, hydrolysis of iron salt and hydrothermal synthesis [7,9,10] . Hydrothermal synthesis has shown to be advantageous over other methods in homogeneous nucleation and grain growth of α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles. In particular, Sorescu et al. [11] have synthesized hematite particles of four different morphologies by the hydrothermal method and have reported for the first time that the particle morphology plays a crucial role in determining the magnetic properties of hematite. In addition, surfactants have been widely employed to synthesize metal oxide nanoparticles in previous literatures [12–14] . For instance, Wang et al. [12] have successfully prepared ZnO, NiO and SnO 2 nanoparticles with cationic surfactant (cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide, CTAB) to be good candidates for obtaining well-dispersed and spherical particles. Chen et al. [13] have prepared different morphological α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles from Fe(OH) 3 gel deposited by anionic surfactant (sodium dodecylebenzene sulphonate, DBS) solution via the solvothermal process in the presence of n -butylalcohol or dimethylbenzene as medium. Liu et al. [14] have fabricated γ-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles coated with DBS or CTAB by the microemulsion method. With regard to the above factors, in this paper, we select two different surfactants to modify the reaction conditions for fabrication of α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles by hydrothermal approach, the main aim is to investigate how different surfactants change the shape and size of the final products and then influence their magnetic properties. The resultant products were characterized by means of Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron micrograph (TEM) combined with electron diffraction (ED) and magnetization measurements. 2 Experimental All chemicals used in our experiments are analytical reagents and used as received. Forty millilitres of 0.6 M NaOH aqueous solution was slowly added to the same volume of 0.1 M (NH 4 ) 3 Fe(C 2 O 4 ) 3 aqueous solution under vigorous stirring until a slurry suspension formed. 0.52 g SDS was then added into the above suspension, followed by additional agitation for 7 h. Subsequently, the mixed system was poured into a Teflon-lined autoclave of 100 ml capacity, sealed into stainless steel tanks and heated at 180 °C for 2 h. After the autoclave was cooled naturally to room temperature, precipitates were collected by centrifugation, washed twice with distilled water and absolute ethanol to remove residual ions and excessive surfactant. Finally, the precipitates were dried at 80 °C for 3 h; a reddish-brown powder was obtained, named as α-Fe 2 O 3 /SDS. Similar procedure was performed to synthesize α-Fe 2 O 3 /HPC, only 3.6 g HPC instead of 0.52 g SDS was added in the reaction process. Product α-Fe 2 O 3 without surfactant was also prepared under the same conditions for comparison. IR spectra in KBr pellets were recorded in the range 4000–400 cm −1 on an American Nicolet AVATAR 380 FT-IR spectrometer. XRD spectra were performed on a Japan Rigaku D/max 2500 XRD with Cu Kα radiation ( λ = 1.5418 Å). The particle morphology and size of the samples were determined on a Holland Phillips EM400ST transmission electron microscopy combined with ED. Magnetic measurements were carried out on an American LDJ 9600 vibrating sample magnetometer with a maximum field of 7.0 kOe at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion The X-ray patterns of the α-Fe 2 O 3 without surfactant, α-Fe 2 O 3 /SDS and α-Fe 2 O 3 /HPC are shown in Fig. 1 a–c , respectively. As expected, the hematite diffraction peaks of them are identical, which are in agreement with the reported values (JCPDS No. 33-663), suggesting that there are no other compounds in presence of the final α-Fe 2 O 3 products. The mean crystallite diameter, calculated by Scherrer’s equation, is found to be 55, 76 and 95 nm for the α-Fe 2 O 3 without surfactant, α-Fe 2 O 3 /SDS and α-Fe 2 O 3 /HPC, respectively. TEM images of the three products are shown in Fig. 2 . It can be found that the TEM pattern of the α-Fe 2 O 3 without surfactant (see Fig. 2 a) shows monodispersed polyhedral shape with particle size of around 90 ± 35 nm, while the α-Fe 2 O 3 /SDS (see Fig. 2 b) shows monodispersed ellipsoidal shape with mean particle size of major axis: ca. 420 nm; minor axis: ca. 205 nm; and the α-Fe 2 O 3 /HPC (see Fig. 2 c) shows monodispersed spherical shape with mean particle size of ca. 185 nm. It is evident that the morphologies transform from irregular to regular, and the particle size of each product is clearly larger than that of the α-Fe 2 O 3 without surfactant, indicating that the surfactants can effectively adjust the shape and size of the particles, and the products modified by the surfactants possess higher crystallinity. However, the particle size of all samples observed from TEM is larger than that calculated by XRD, revealing that the monodispersed particles are polycrystalline in nature, consisting of large numbers of smaller subparticles of tens of nanometers. Similar polycrystalline behavior has also been reported by other authors [15–19] . In addition, the corresponding ED patterns of the three samples (inserted in Fig. 2 a–c) show several diffused rings, respectively, indicative of a fine crystallite size character. This is in accordance with our result. IR spectra of α-Fe 2 O 3 /HPC, α-Fe 2 O 3 /SDS and α-Fe 2 O 3 without surfactant are shown in Fig. 3 a–c , respectively. It can be seen that the IR spectra of them present similar trends. The dominant bands of the three products (at about 472 and 570 cm −1 ) are characteristic of crystalline α-Fe 2 O 3 [20] . The bands around 3430 and 1636 cm −1 in all samples are assigned to the stretching vibration of OH groups and bending vibration of water molecules, respectively [21] . Interestingly, the absorption peak at 475 cm −1 hardly changes from Fig. 3 a–c, suggesting that this peak has not been affected in our experimental conditions. But the dominant absorption peak at 570 cm −1 shifts to somewhat lower frequencies and becomes broader from Fig. 3 a–c when the mean crystallite diameter decreases. It is probably due to the changes of the morphology and the internal structure of the particles [22] , since the obtained particles consist of large numbers of smaller subparticles. Hence, when the mean crystallite diameter decreases, the absorption peak become broader, which can be explained by the facts that the subparticles closely attached in a particle are subjected to some dipole–dipole interactions. Consequently, phonons cannot be confined within each subparticle unit, but can pass across the subparticle boundaries to be delocalized in a whole particle. As a result, the collective infrared properties of the subparticles are basically similar to a single-crystalline particle. However, there must be anharmonic potentials around the subparticle boundaries, created mainly by the dipolar even high multipolar interactions between subparticles, which may accelerate the decay of the phonons, resulting in the substantial peak broadening. This effect is pronounced with the decreasing mean crystallite diameter due to the higher density of the subparticle boundaries. Magnetic hysteresis measurements for the three products were carried out in applied magnetic field at room temperature and the related magnetic parameters are listed in Table 1 . The hysteresis loops of all products (see Fig. 4 ) do not reach saturation up to the maximum applied magnetic field. It can be also seen from Fig. 4 a that the data show no hysteresis (immeasurable remanent magnetization and very lower coercivity), indicating that the α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles without surfactant are superparamagnetic. However, the magnetization measurements of the α-Fe 2 O 3 /HPC and α-Fe 2 O 3 /SDS (see Fig. 4 b–c) exhibit hysteretic feature with the remanent magnetization and coercivity being determined to be 0.08445 emu/g and 300.2 Oe, 0.06154 emu/g and 442.6 Oe, respectively, suggesting that the α-Fe 2 O 3 /HPC and α-Fe 2 O 3 /SDS are weak ferromagnetic at room temperature. It is found that the remanent magnetization and coercivity increase after the α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles modified by two surfactants, indicating the surfactants can affect the products’ magnetic characteristics in our experimental conditions. This phenomenon can be explained as follows: (1) Since the obtained particles are polycrystalline which consist of large numbers of smaller subparticles inside them. After the α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles modified by the surfactants, the particle size increases compared with that of the α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles without surfactant; so, the number of the subparticles increases, which can result in the enhancement in coercivity. Our opinion is basically coincident with the earlier reports [15,16] . (2) There is a possibility that after the products modified by surfactants, the increase in coercivity may be associated with a corresponding change from the multidomain to single domain. (3) Surfactants mainly affect the particle surface, thus, the change of the particle surface can result in the spin pinning owing to the increase of the magnetic surface anisotropy, and then influence the magnetic nature. Of course, our view should be further confirmed by more experimental evidences. 4 Conclusion Monodispersed ellipsoidal and spherical shape α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles modified by SDS and HPC, respectively, have been synthesized via hydrothermal method, using (NH 4 ) 3 Fe(C 2 O 4 ) 3 and NaOH as starting materials. It can be seen from TEM that the α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles without surfactant show monodispersed polyhedral shape with particle size of around 90 ± 35 nm, while the α-Fe 2 O 3 /SDS nanoparticles show monodispersed ellipsoidal shape with mean particle size of major axis: ca. 420 nm; minor axis: ca. 205 nm; and the α-Fe 2 O 3 /HPC nanoparticles show monodispersed spherical shape with mean particle size of ca. 185 nm. It is evident that the morphologies transform from irregular to regular, and the particle size of each product is clearly larger than that of the α-Fe 2 O 3 without surfactant, indicating that the surfactants can effectively adjust the shape, and size of the particles and the products modified by the surfactants possess higher crystallinity. At the same time, after the products modified by the surfactants, the increase in coercivity may be associated with a corresponding change from the multidomain to single domain, the increase of the number of the subparticles and the increase of the magnetic surface anisotropy. Magnetization measurements reveal that the α-Fe 2 O 3 nanoparticles without surfactant exhibit superparamagnetic behavior at room temperature, however, the other two products modified by SDS and HPC all show weak ferromagnetic properties. Thus, it can be concluded that the surfactants not only significantly influence the size and shape of the particles, but also their magnetic properties. Hence, this paper presents a new synthetic strategy to obtain various size, shape and magnetic nanoparticles via hydrothermal route for specific industrial applications. References [1] R.H. CGOCLCd5.title: Preparation and characterization of CuO/CeO2 catalysts and their applications in low-temperature CO oxidation
CGOCLCd5.abstract: CeO 2 nanoparticles were prepared by thermal decomposition of cerous nitrate and then used as supports for CuO/CeO 2 catalysts prepared via the impregnation method. The samples were characterized by HRTEM, XRD, H 2 -TPR, and XPS. The catalytic properties of the prepared catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation were studied by using a microreactor–GC system. The results showed that the thermal decomposition temperature affected the physical properties of the prepared CeO 2 particles, such as particle size and morphology. The loading of CuO in non-crystalline forms on CeO 2 supports was different in the CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. The loading of non-crystalline CuO was higher on the CeO 2 prepared via thermal decomposition at 500 °C than those on the CeO 2 prepared via thermal decomposition at 400, 600 and 700 °C. One part of the non-crystalline CuO in CuO/CeO 2 catalysts entered the CeO 2 lattice and the other part dispersed over the CeO 2 surface. Calcination temperature had little effect on the catalytic activity when it was lower than 600 °C. However, heating the catalysts to higher temperatures (i.e. 800 °C) had a significant impact on the catalytic activity because the crystallite size rapidly grows and more CuO and CeO 2 phase-separation occurs. Keywords Thermal decomposition Ceria CuO/CeO 2 catalysts Low-temperature CO oxidation 1 Introduction Catalysts based on ceria present a wide range of applications, such as three-way catalysts for automobile exhaust gas emission control, removal of SO x –NO x from fluid catalytic cracking flue gases, electrocatalysts over fuel cell electrodes, and catalysts for various oxidation and hydrogenation reactions [1] . For such applications, especially for automobile exhaust gas emission control, CeO 2 performs the following functions: (1) it stabilizes the catalyst against metal dispersion; (2) it stores and releases oxygen; and (3) it improves CO oxidation and NO x reduction [2] . On the other hand, copper-based catalysts have recently attracted much attention in heterogeneous catalysis because of their high catalytic activities toward NO and CO and hydrocarbon oxidation [3] . In recent years, the Cu–Ce–O system has been found to be effective catalyst for low-temperature CO oxidation and was widely studied with the hope that it could be used as a replacement for expensive precious metal catalysts [1,2,4–16] . In our early work [4–10] , we prepared Cu–Ce–O catalysts via solvated metal atom impregnation, sol–gel, alcohothermal synthesis combined with impregnation method. We investigated the structures of CeO 2 and Cu–Ce–O catalysts by UV–vis, FT-Raman, XRD, SEM, HRTEM, BET, TPR and XPS, and we studied their catalytic activity in low-temperature CO oxidation. In this paper, we report the low-temperature CO oxidation properties of CuO/CeO 2 composite catalysts prepared via thermal decomposition combined with impregnation. The prepared CeO 2 nanoparticles and CuO/CeO 2 composite catalysts were characterized by means of various technologies and the catalytic activity was studied by using a microreactor–GC system. The effect of thermal decomposition temperature on the CeO 2 physical properties and the corresponding CuO/CeO 2 catalyst activity valves in CO oxidation were studied in detail. Furthermore, the CuO/CeO 2 catalyst pretreatment effects on the catalytic activity were also studied. The information gained may aid the development of Cu–Ce–O catalysts, which may replace precious metal catalysts for the low-temperature CO oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation CeO 2 was prepared by thermal decomposition of cerous nitrate, Ce(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O, for 4 h at 400, 500, 600, or 700 °C in air, respectively. The prepared buff particles are denoted as CeO 2 -A, CeO 2 -B, CeO 2 -C and CeO 2 -D, in turn. The supported CuO/CeO 2 composite catalysts were prepared by the conventional wet impregnation method. The prepared CeO 2 supports were impregnated with an aqueous solution of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 ·3H 2 O for 5 h and excess water was then vaporized at 60 °C by heating. The obtained materials were dried overnight in an oven at 80 °C and calcined in air for 3.5 h at 300, 400, 500, 600, or 800 °C, respectively. The prepared catalysts are denoted as CuO/CeO 2 -A, CuO/CeO 2 -B, CuO/CeO 2 -C and CuO/CeO 2 -D. The final loading of CuO for all the samples was 6.3 wt.%. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The morphology and crystal analysis of the prepared CeO 2 particles were studied by using a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) linked with a Philips T20ST transmission electron microscope operated at 200 kV. The crystalline structures of the prepared CeO 2 and CuO/CeO 2 catalysts were analyzed by using a DMAX-2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The working voltage and current of the X-ray tube were 40 kV and 100 mA. The average crystalline size was calculated from the X-ray line broadening, according to Scherrer's equation [17] . Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were performed with H 2 as reductant using Autochem 2910 Micromeritics (USA) instrument. The reduction gas was a mixture of 5% H 2 in N 2 flowing at 30 mL min −1 . The heating rate was 10 °C min −1 . The H 2 uptake amount during the reduction was measured using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a PHI-1600 spectrometer (USA) equipped with a Mg Kα radiation source for exciting photoelectrons. The X-ray source was operated at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV and 250 W. The pressure in the ion-pumped analysis chamber was maintained at 8 × 10 −10 Torr (1 Torr = 133.33 Pa) during data acquisition. All binding energies (BE) were referenced to the adventitious C 1s line at 284.6 eV (1 eV = 1.602 × 10 −19 J). 2.3 Catalytic studies The activity of the catalyst samples was tested using a fixed bed flow microreactor under atmospheric pressure. Fifty milligrams of catalyst powder was diluted with 2 g of fine quartz sand. The gases contained 1.0% CO balanced with air and the total gas flow rate were 33.6 mL min −1 . The reactant and product composition were analyzed on-line with a GC-508A gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Fig. 1 illustrates the HRTEM images of the prepared CeO 2 particles. One can see from Fig. 1 , the HRTEM patterns of the CeO 2 -A and CeO 2 -B showed mostly regular spherical shapes. Furthermore, the ratio of spherical particles decreased with the increasing of thermal decomposition temperature. The morphology of CeO 2 -C became obviously irregular and CeO 2 -D showed various shapes, such as spherical, claviform, subuliform and rhombohedral. In addition, the HRTEM picture of CeO 2 -D shows obviously larger particle sizes than were present in the pictures of CeO 2 -A, CeO 2 -B and CeO 2 -C. The results indicated that the thermal decomposition temperature affected the physical properties of the prepared CeO 2 particles such as particle size and morphology, which are of critical importance for its applications in catalysis [18] . On the other hand, the SAED patterns in Fig. 1 indicate that the prepared CeO 2 was crystalline in local area while the different grain boundaries indicated that the material was polycrystalline overall. The XRD patterns of the prepared CeO 2 -A, CeO 2 -B, CeO 2 -C and CeO 2 -D particles are presented in Fig. 2 a–d, respectively. All the peaks could be indexed to the cubic phase of ceria with fluorite structure (JCPDS Data File # 43-1002). Furthermore, when the heating temperature was between 300 and 600 °C, it had no obvious effect on the broadenings and relative peak intensity of CeO 2 phase. When the heating temperature rose to 700 °C, however, the temperature effect became obvious, indicating that the crystallites were much larger. The average crystallite size of CeO 2 was 17.5, 18.2, 19.1 and 39.6 nm for CeO 2 -A, CeO 2 -B, CeO 2 -C and CeO 2 -D, respectively. The results agreed with the above results of HRTEM analyses. The X-ray patterns of CuO/CeO 2 -A, CuO/CeO 2 -B, CuO/CeO 2 -C and CuO/CeO 2 -D catalysts calcined in air for 3.5 h at elevated temperatures are shown in Figs. 3–6 , respectively. The distinct CeO 2 fluorite-type oxide structure was presented in all samples. Furthermore, when the calcination temperature was lower than 600 °C, it had no obvious effect on the broadenings and relative peak intensity of CeO 2 phase; the average sizes of CeO 2 particles listed in Table 1 were thus close to each other. When the calcination temperature rose to 800 °C, the temperature effect became obvious and the CeO 2 particle size was much larger than before. This indicates that only high temperature treatment affects the degree of crystallinity and the particle size of CeO 2 phase obviously. On the other hand, no obvious diffraction lines due to CuO were detected even when the 2 θ (30–50°) was expanded where CuO peaks are expected for CuO/CeO 2 -A and CuO/CeO 2 -B catalysts calcined at 300–600 °C. Only weak peaks attributed to CuO crystal phase appeared until the calcination temperature rose to 800 °C for CuO/CeO 2 -A and CuO/CeO 2 -B catalysts and for all the CuO/CeO 2 -C and CuO/CeO 2 -D catalysts, indicating that most of CuO was non-crystalline. This result was due to the fine dispersion of CuO on the CeO 2 surface, to Cu–Ce–O solid solution formation or to a combination of the above two phenomena [14] . The XRD analyses indicate that both the physical properties of CeO 2 supports and the calcination temperatures affected the ratio of CuO in non-crystalline forms. In order to verify the state of non-crystalline CuO, we did XRD analyses that emphasized the microstructure of pure CeO 2 -B and CuO/CeO 2 -B catalyst. The two samples were pretreated in air at 500 °C for 3.5 h. The results showed that the cell parameter and cell volume value of pure CeO 2 -B was 0.5409 nm and 0.1582 nm 3 , respectively. After CuO and CeO 2 -B formed CuO/CeO 2 -B catalyst, the cell parameter and cell volume value of CeO 2 -B was 0.5402 nm and 0.1576 nm 3 , respectively (i.e. smaller than the values of pure CeO 2 -B), indicating that some non-crystalline CuO had entered the CeO 2 -B lattice, as the Cu 2+ ion radius (0.076 nm) is smaller than that of Ce 4+ (0.101 nm). Therefore, the CeO 2 particles in CuO/CeO 2 catalysts calcined at low temperatures (≤500 °C) are smaller than the particles of pure CeO 2 supports. The typical TPR profiles of CuO/CeO 2 -A, CuO/CeO 2 -B, CuO/CeO 2 -C, and CuO/CeO 2 -D catalysts calcined at 500 °C are shown in Fig. 7 a–d. The TPR profile of CuO/CeO 2 -A showed mainly one reduction peak at about 183 °C. In addition, there were two shoulder peaks at about 137 and 215 °C ( Fig. 7 a). The reduction features of the CuO/CeO 2 -B catalyst, shown in Fig. 7 b, were different from those of the CuO/CeO 2 -A catalyst. Two overlapping reduction peaks with higher intensity at about 134 and 204 °C were present. The reduction profile of CuO/CeO 2 -C catalyst were characterized by a weak peak and a strong peak at 140 and 199 °C, respectively. In addition, there was a shoulder peak at about 218 °C. The reduction profile of CuO/CeO 2 -D catalyst was characterized by a weak peak and a strong peak at 138 and 219 °C, respectively. In addition, there was a very weak shoulder peak at about 160 °C. The TPR profiles of CuO/CeO 2 -C catalysts calcined at 300 or 800 °C are shown in Fig. 8 . The reduction profiles of CuO/CeO 2 -C catalysts calcined at 300 °C was characterized by a reduction peak (α peak) and a stronger peak (β peak) at about 140 and about 199 °C, respectively. In addition, there was a shoulder peak at about 218 °C (γ peak). However, The TPR profile of CuO/CeO 2 -C calcined at 800 °C showed mainly one reduction peak (δ peak) at about 248 °C. The presence of more than one reduction peak in all the present samples is an indication of the existence of more than one copper oxide species in the prepared CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. A great amount of literature data is available for TPR studies of Cu-based catalysts. The synergistic interaction between the CuO and CeO 2 support is more evident from the decrease in the reduction temperatures of both CuO moieties and CeO 2 support. The TPR peak shape and position highly depend on the experimental conditions and the catalyst system. Liu and Flytzani-Stephanopoulos [19] reported two reduction peaks, where reduction of copper oxide clusters strongly interacting with ceria, was observed in the range of 125–175 °C, while larger CuO particles, non-associated with CeO 2 , were reduced at ∼200 °C. Ranga et al. [20] attributed the TPR peaks at 145 and 170 °C of CuO/CeO 2 samples to highly dispersed CuO and to fairly large clusters of CuO on CeO 2 surface, respectively. Jiang et al. [2] also observed two reduction peaks for CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. The peak at lower temperature represented small CuO particles interacted with CeO 2 which were highly dispersed. Another one at higher temperature represented larger bulk CuO particles interacted with CeO 2 . Wrobel et al. [21] reported copper reduction in the range of 120–150 °C for CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. Similar results were also reported by Ratnasamy et al. [22] , where two overlapping reductions were attributed to dispersed copper oxide clusters, strongly interacting with CeO 2 and CuO particles. In addition, George and Theophilos [23] observed there were three overlapping reduction peaks: a low-intensity, low-temperature peak at 168 °C attributed to reduction of copper ions strongly interacting with CeO 2 and two peaks of higher intensity at 210 and 255 °C that represented the reduction of larger CuO particles less associated with ceria. Even so, these CuO particles had to be of smaller size compared to those of pure CuO, as they also reduced at lower temperatures. Tang et al. [24] also observed three reduction peaks: The first peak was ascribed to the reduction of CuO on the ceria surface; the second one was ascribed to the reduction of larger CuO species on the surface; and the third peak was ascribed to the reduction of bulk CuO and surface CeO 2 . Similar results were also reported by Dong et al. [25] . Based on the above, the TPR peaks at the range of 134–140 °C (or α) and 183–204 °C (or β) of CuO/CeO 2 -A,CuO/CeO 2 -B and CuO/CeO 2 -C samples may be attributed to reduction of non-crystalline CuO strongly interacting with CeO 2 and the reduction of larger CuO particles weakly associated with CeO 2 , respectively. The peak at 215 °C of the CuO/CeO 2 -A sample, the γ peak of the CuO/CeO 2 -C sample and the peak at 219 °C of the CuO/CeO 2 -D sample probably represented the reduction of bulk copper oxide (crystalline forms) which associated with CeO 2 to some extent. The δ peak of the CuO/CeO 2 -C sample represented the reduction of pure bulk copper oxide. The difference between the two kinds of bulk CuO phases needs further study. The typical spectra of Ce 3d and Cu 2p binding energies of the CuO/CeO 2 -C catalyst calcined in air at 500 °C for 3.5 h are shown in Fig. 9 . In Fig. 9 a, Ce 3d shows mainly five peaks at about 881.9, 888.4, 897.7, 900.2, and 906.9 eV, which was similar to the reported peaks of Ce 4+ [26] , indicating the main valence of CeO 2 in the prepared CuO/CeO 2 catalysts was 4+. The peaks of Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2 were centered at 932.1 and 952.1 eV, respectively. The Cu 2p 3/2 value of the samples was lower than that of CuO, i.e. 933.6 eV [23] . This may suggest the presence of reduced copper species in the prepared CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. The Cu 2p 3/2 value cannot, however, be used to distinguish between Cu 2 O and Cu 0 because they are essentially identical. 3.2 Catalytic activity for CO oxidation The light-off curves over the prepared CuO/CeO 2 -A, CuO/CeO 2 -B, CuO/CeO 2 -C and CuO/CeO 2 -D catalysts are presented in Figs. 10–13 , respectively. The catalytic activity valves of pure CeO 2 -A, CeO 2 -B, CeO 2 -C and CeO 2 -D are also included in the corresponding figure for comparison purposes. One should note that the CO conversion increased with increasing reaction temperature for all the present catalysts. The activity of pure CeO 2 was quite low, and the activity of the CuO/CeO 2 catalysts, except for those calcined at 800 °C, was much higher than that of pure CeO 2 . The pure CuO (thermal decomposition of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 at 500 °C for 3.5 h) had no catalytic activity under the present condition. This indicated that there is a synergistic effect between the CuO and CeO 2 support that is responsible for the high activity of CO oxidation. It is clear from Figs. 10–13 that the light-off temperatures of CuO/CeO 2 -A, CuO/CeO 2 -B and CuO/CeO 2 -C catalysts are lower than that of CuO/CeO 2 -D catalysts under the reaction conditions. When the catalysts were calcined at 300–600 °C, the reaction temperature ranges for CO full conversion of CuO/CeO 2 -A, CuO/CeO 2 -B and CuO/CeO 2 -C catalysts was 140–160, 140–160 and 140–170 °C, respectively. However, the reaction temperature for CO full conversion of CuO/CeO 2 -D catalysts was 200–210 °C. The combined results of the HRTEM, XRD and TPR analyses show that the various CeO 2 supports had different surface defects that led to the loading differences of non-crystalline CuO which entered into the ceria lattice or dispersed on the ceria surface. Liu and Flytzani-Stephanopoulos [16] suggested that the activity of Cu–Ce–O catalyst derived primarily from the combination of finely dispersed copper–cerium oxide systems, and bulk copper oxides gave negligible contributions. Luo et al. [27] also suggested that the dispersed CuO was responsible for the low-temperature CO oxidation in CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. The results indicated that CeO 2 supports affect the synergistic effect, subsequently affect the catalytic activity of the corresponding CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. From Fig. 10 , one can see that the catalytic activity valves of CuO/CeO 2 -A catalysts calcined at 300–600 °C were very close to each other when the reaction temperature was in the 80–100 °C region. When the reaction temperature increased further, the catalysts calcined at 400–600 °C exhibited higher catalytic activity than that calcined at 300 °C. The reaction temperature for full CO conversion over the former catalysts decreased by 20 °C compared with that over the latter one. However, the CuO/CeO 2 -A catalysts calcined at 300–600 °C exhibited much higher catalytic activity than that calcined at 800 °C. Similar results were also observed in Fig. 11 . The catalytic activity of CuO/CeO 2 -B catalysts calcined at 500 and 600 °C was higher than that of CuO/CeO 2 -B catalysts calcined at 300 and 400 °C. But the activity difference was not so obvious and the former catalysts exhibited much higher catalytic activity than that calcined at 800 °C. Fig. 12 shows the activity sequence of the present CuO/CeO 2 -C catalysts: sample calcined at 600 °C ≥ sample calcined at 500 °C > sample calcined at 400 °C > sample calcined at 300 °C ≥ sample calcined at 800 °C. Fig. 13 presents an activity sequence similar to that in Fig. 12 . The CuO/CeO 2 -D catalyst calcined at 800 °C exhibited the lowest catalytic activity. On the other hand, when the reaction temperature is in the 90–130 °C regions, the CuO/CeO 2 -D catalyst calcined at 600 °C exhibited the highest activity. When the temperature increased further, it still remained the highest activity but the catalysts calcined at 300–500 °C exhibited closer activity values. In summary, the prepared CuO/CeO 2 activity increased with the increasing of the calcination temperature and reached a maximum where the calcination temperature was at about 600 °C; then the activity decreased with the increasing of calcination temperature. The results indicate that calcination temperature is an important factor for the activity of the CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. As mentioned above, the finely dispersed CuO on CeO 2 , i.e. the non-crystal form CuO, is responsible for the low-temperature CO oxidation, and the bulk CuO contributes little to, even deteriorates, the activity. From XRD, TPR and catalytic activity results, heating the catalyst to temperature over 800 °C has a significant impact on the catalytic activity because of the rapid growth of crystallite size and more CuO and CeO 2 phase-separation. Compared to CuO/CeO 2 catalysts prepared via other techniques that we have reported [4,6–10] , the catalysts prepared via thermal decomposition combined with impregnation method exhibited similar or even better catalytic performances under the same reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions In this paper, CeO 2 nanoparticles with different physical properties were prepared via a thermal decomposition method. Four series of CuO/CeO 2 catalysts were prepared by a impregnation technique and tested for low-temperature carbon monoxide oxidation. H 2 -TPR indicated the existence of more than one copper oxide species in the CuO/CeO 2 catalysts and the loading of non-crystalline CuO varied with different physical properties of CeO 2 -supported CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. XPS analysis indicated that the main valence state of cerium was 4+ and that the reduced copper species were present in the prepared CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. The physical properties of CeO 2 supports affect the catalytic activity of the CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. High temperature (i.e. 600 °C) calcination made CuO disperse on CeO 2 better and helped to increase catalytic activity of the CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. But the higher temperatures (i.e. 800 °C) had a significant impact on the catalytic activity because of the rapid growth of crystallite size and more CuO and CeO 2 phase-separation. The thermal decomposition combined with the impregnation method appears to be a simple and effective method for the preparation of CuO/CeO 2 catalysts. LUU3ami0.title: Effects of the specific area and the thermal stability of a polymer on the catalytic activities of polymer immobilized Co-Pd catalysts by SAMI
LUU3ami0.abstract: Co-Pd bimetallic catalysts immobilized with four kinds of resins with different specific areas were prepared by means of the solvated metal atom impregnation (SMAI) method. The results of the XRD and the magnetic measurement showed that as the specific area of the resin increased, the particle sizes of Co and Pd on the catalysts with the same metal content decreased, so the catalytic activity of the catalysts for the hydrogenation of diacetone alcohol as well as the reduction of oxygen on the fuel cell electrode increased. Below 140 °C, the conversion of diacetone alcohol increased as the reaction temperature increased, and above 140 °C, the conversion decreased because of the rupture of the resin.

GdbTSWcI.title: Enhanced sensor response of Ni-doped SnO2 hollow spheres
GdbTSWcI.abstract: A novel sensing material of Ni-doped SnO 2 hollow spheres was prepared and characterized by X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy. Gas sensing properties of the sensor fabricated from the as-prepared Ni-doped SnO 2 hollow spheres were systematically investigated and compared with those of pristine SnO 2 hollow spheres. Results showed that the Ni-doped sensor had a good selectivity to higher alcohols such as n-butanol with much higher response, while the undoped sensor exhibited poor response to all the tested gases with poor selectivity. The enhanced sensor performances are probably attributed to the formation of p–n heterojunctions between p-type NiO and n-type SnO 2 . It also suggests that the Ni-dopant is a promising substitute for noble metal additives to fabricate sensor materials with a low cost.

5p7167qc.title: Catalytic carbon monoxide oxidation over CuO/CeO2 composite catalysts
5p7167qc.abstract: CeO2 nanoparticles were prepared by thermal decomposition of cerous nitrate and then used as supports for CuO/CeO2 catalysts prepared via the impregnation method. The samples were characterized by XRD, HRTEM, H2-TPR and XPS. The catalytic properties of the catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation were studied by using a microreactor-GC system. © Springer-Verlag/Akadémiai Kiadó 2006.

bYL9UJjY.title: A DRIFTS study of low-temperature CO oxidation over Au/SnO2 catalyst prepared by co-precipitation method
bYL9UJjY.abstract: An in situ DRIFTS study of the adsorption and oxidation of CO on the Au/SnO 2 catalyst prepared by a co-precipitation method was presented. The results indicated that (1) at relatively low-temperature, CO adsorbed on the catalyst reacted with the surface lattice oxygens and hydroxyl groups to form carboxylate, which further reacted with the surface lattice oxygens and hydroxyl groups to form carbonate at relatively high temperature. (2) O 2 mainly acted as an activator for the reaction of CO with the surface lattice oxygens and hydroxyl groups, but it did not participate directly in the formation of carboxylate and carbonate.

XnkIMufA.title: Porous alpha-Fe2O3 decorated by Au nanoparticles and their enhanced sensor performance.
XnkIMufA.abstract: Porous alpha-Fe(2)O(3) was synthesized by simple calcination of a beta-FeOOH precursor derived from a facile hydrothermal method. In the hydrothermal process, only FeCl(3).6H(2)O was used as the source material and no templates or pore-directing agents were needed. The as-prepared porous alpha-Fe(2)O(3) was further employed as a support for loading Au nanoparticles (AuNPs). Due to the advantages of porous nanostructures (large surface area and facile gas diffusion) and the catalytic capability of AuNPs, the derived AuNP-supported porous alpha-Fe(2)O(3) was further investigated for gas sensor applications using ethanol as a probe molecule. Obtained results showed that the AuNP-supported porous alpha-Fe(2)O(3) exhibited a much higher response in comparison to pure alpha-Fe(2)O(3). The enhanced sensor properties are attributed to the unique porous structures of the alpha-Fe(2)O(3) support and active AuNPs for promoting sensing reactions, as well as the synergic electronic interaction between Au and alpha-Fe(2)O(3). It is expected that noble metals such as Ag, Pt and Pd can also be supported on other porous metal oxide semiconductors to explore superior properties of functional nanomaterials.

I1hImF7T.title: Polypyrrole-coated sno2 hollow spheres and their application for ammonia sensor
I1hImF7T.abstract: Polypyrrole-coated SnO2 hollow spheres hybrid materials have been synthesized through an in situ polymerization of pyrrole monomers in the presence of preprepared SnO2 hollow spheres. The hybrids were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR), and thermogravimetric analysis (TG). Experimental data showed certain synergetic interaction existed in the hybrids, probably resulting in the enhanced thermal stability of polypyrrole coatings. Gas sensing tests showed that the hybrids possessed very fast response and high sensitivity to ammonia gas at room temperature, implying its potential application for gas sensors. © 2009 American Chemical Society.

zmvYsHIh.title: Synthesis and characterization of porous metal-organic framework MOF-5
zmvYsHIh.abstract: The study on porous metal-organic frameworks(MOFs) is one of the most attractive areas in the research field of inorganic chemistry.In this contribution,the synthesis and structure characterization of MOF-5 were introduced as an inorganic chemistry experiment,which combined the methods of the synthesis of transition metal salts and MOFs with the modern instrumental analysis technology.The structure and the phase purity can be confirmed by the comparison of PXRD patter of products with simulated XRD pattern for MOF-5 crystal.The N2 adsorption properties were also studied.

CDvWGBMm.title: Synthesis and gas sensing properties of α-Fe(2)O(3)@ZnO core-shell nanospindles.
CDvWGBMm.abstract: α-Fe(2)O(3)@ZnO core-shell nanospindles were synthesized via a two-step hydrothermal approach, and characterized by means of SEM/TEM/XRD/XPS. The ZnO shell coated on the nanospindles has a thickness of 10-15 nm. Considering that both α-Fe(2)O(3) and ZnO are good sensing materials, we have investigated the gas sensing performances of the core-shell nanocomposite using ethanol as the main probe gas. It is interesting to find that the gas sensor properties of the core-shell nanospindles are significantly enhanced compared with pristine α-Fe(2)O(3). The enhanced sensor properties are attributed to the unique core-shell nanostructure. The detailed sensing mechanism is discussed with respect to the energy band structure and the electron depletion theory. The core-shell nanostructure reported in this work provides a new path to fabricate highly sensitive materials for gas sensing applications.
